Sec. 704.2 SMOKE ALARMS. 
Single- or multiple-station smoke alarms shall be installed and maintained in Group R-2, R-3 or R-4 and in dwellings not regulated in Group R occupancies, regardless of occupant load at all of the following locations: 
1.  On the ceiling or wall outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of bedrooms. 
2.  In each room used for sleeping purposes. 
3.  In each story within a dwelling unit, including basements and cellars but not including crawl spaces and uninhabitable attics. In dwellings or dwelling units with split levels and without an intervening door between the adjacent levels, a smoke alarm installed on the upper level shall suffice for the adjacent lower level provided that the lower level is less than one full story below the upper level. 
Single- or multiple-station smoke alarms shall be installed in other groups in accordance with the International Fire Code, Michigan Building Code and Michigan Residential Code. 
(60)  Section 704.3. is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Sec. 704.3 POWER SOURCE. 
In Group R occupancies and in dwellings not regulated as Group R occupancies, single-station smoke alarms shall receive their primary power from the building wiring provided that such wiring is served from a commercial source and shall be equipped with a batter backup. Smoke alarms shall emit a signal when the batteries are low. Wiring shall be permanent and without a disconnecting switch other than as required for overcurrent protection. 
Exception: Smoke alarms are permitted to be solely battery operated in buildings where no construction is taking place, buildings that are not served from a commercial power source and in existing areas of buildings undergoing alterations or repairs that do not result in the removal of interior wall or ceiling finishes exposing the structure, unless there is an attic, crawl space or basement available which could provide access for building wiring without the removal of interior finishes. Where allowed, battery powered smoke detectors shall be energized with not less than a five-year battery. 
(Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 11-17-08; Ord. No. 8-09, §§ 1-3, 5, 12-21-09; Ord. No. 5-15, § 1, 6-1-15; Ord. No. 2-18, §§ 1, 2, 3-19-18; Ord. No. 9-18, § 1, 6-18-18) 
Sec. 10-180. - Savings. 
    All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired or incurred at the time of the effective date of this article are saved and may be completed according to the law in force when this article takes effect. 
(Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 11-17-08) 
Secs. 10-181-10-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BANNERS, STREAMERS AND PENNANTS 

Sec. 10-381. - Findings of fact. 
    The city council hereby determines that banners, streamers, pennants and other temporary indoor and outdoor signs tend to deteriorate, become loose or fall off the structures to which they are attached thereby causing litter to accumulate and becoming a potential hazard to pedestrians and motorists. The city council further determines that due to the deterioration of these types of signs and displays they constitute a potential blighting influence or tendency within the city and therefore should be eliminated. This determination is made based upon the information provided to the council by the inspections department of the city and on the fact that the zoning code of the city regulates the installation of new banners, streamers, pennants and window signs. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 10-382. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter the following definitions shall apply: 
    Banner. A sign made of fabric, cloth, paper or other nonrigid material that is typically not enclosed in a frame. 
    Pennant. A generally triangular tapering flag or banner hung from a building, post, pole, wire or other device. 
    Public service announcement. An announcement on a banner or similar temporary sign placed by the city for purposes of advertising a community or civic event. 
    Streamer. Long narrow flag(s) or pennant(s) generally hung from a building, pole, post, wire or other type of line. 
    Window sign. A sign located in or on and affixed to a window, which is intended to be viewed from the outside. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 10-383. - Prohibition. 
    Except as provided herein, no person shall place, have placed or allow the placement and maintenance of any banner, pennant, streamer or window sign on any property within the city except in compliance with City Code, chapter 90, article XXIII, signs. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 10-384. - Public service announcements. 
    A banner containing a public service announcement may be placed on public property by the city for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 10-385. - Removal. 
    All banners, pennants, streamers and window signs, except as provided in City Code, chapter 90, article XXIII, signs, shall be removed from any property in the city by the owner, tenant or person in charge of the property within 90 days from the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 10-386. - City removal. 
    Should any prohibited banner, pennant, streamer or window sign be placed or remain on any property after the period provided in this chapter, the city shall have the right to enter on to the property and remove the offending object or objects. Notice of intent to remove shall be provided to the owner, tenant or person in charge of the property as determined by city records by first class mail to that address at least 14 days before removal. Cost of removal together with a 50-percent administrative fee may be assessed against the property, be added to the tax roll and be collected in the same manner as property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Secs. 10-387-10-425. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CONSTRUCTION BOARD OF APPEALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-111 et seq.; board of zoning appeals, § 90-721 et seq. 

Sec. 10-426. - Application for appeal. 
    Any person shall have the right to appeal a decision of the building official under this chapter or such other provisions of the Code as shall specifically provide for such an appeal to the construction board of appeals. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this Code has been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this Code do not fully apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be used. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.201), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-427. - Creation and membership. 
    There is hereby created a construction board of appeals. The board of appeals shall consist of five members appointed by the city manager, subject to the confirmation of a majority of the city council, as follows: three for one year and two for two years. Thereafter, each new member shall serve for three years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.202), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-428. - Qualifications of members. 
    The construction board of appeals shall consist of five individuals, one from each of the following professions or disciplines: 
(1)  A registered design professional that is a registered architect, or a builder or superintendent of building construction. 
(2)  A registered design professional with structural engineering or architectural experience. 
(3)  A registered design professional with mechanical or plumbing engineering experience, or a mechanical or plumbing contractor. 
(4)  A registered design professional with electrical engineering experience, or an electrical contractor. 
(5)  A registered design professional with fire protection engineering experience, or a fire protection contractor. 
If the city is unable to obtain members with the qualifications set forth in this section, the city may appoint members whose experience and qualifications are as close as possible to such qualifications. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.203), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-429. - Alternate members. 
    The city manager, subject to the confirmation of a majority of the city council, may appoint two alternate members of the construction board of appeals who shall be called by the board chairman to hear appeals during the absence or disqualification of a member. Alternate members shall possess the qualifications required for board membership, and shall be appointed for three years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.204), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-430. - Disqualification of member. 
    A member of the construction board of appeals shall not hear an appeal in which that member has any personal, professional or financial interest. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.205), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-431. - Chairman. 
    The construction board of appeals shall annually select one of its members to serve as chairman. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.206), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-432. - Secretary. 
    The building official shall designate a qualified city employee to serve as secretary to the construction board of appeals. The secretary shall file a detailed record of all proceedings in the office of the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.207), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-433. - Compensation of members. 
    Compensation of members of the construction board of appeals shall be determined by the city council in the same manner as other city boards and commissions. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.208), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-434. - Notice of meeting. 
    The construction board of appeals shall meet upon notice from the secretary, within 30 days of the filing of an appeal, or at stated periodic meetings. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.209), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-435. - Open hearing. 
    All hearings before the construction board of appeals shall be open to the public. The appellant, the appellant's representative, the building official and any person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.210), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-436. - Hearing procedures. 
    The construction board of appeals shall adopt and make available to the public through the secretary procedures under which a hearing will be conducted. The procedures shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.211), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-437. - Postponed hearing. 
    When at least four members of the construction board of appeals are not present to hear an appeal, either the appellant or the appellant's representative shall have the right to request a postponement of the hearing. If the appeal specifically relates to the expertise of the absent member, the board may postpone the hearing on its own motion. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.212), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-438. - Board decision. 
    The construction board of appeals may modify or reverse the decision of the code official by a concurring vote of three members. Any decision of the board shall be in writing. Copies shall be furnished to the appellant and the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.213), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-439. - Administration of decision. 
    The building official shall take immediate action in accordance with the decision of the construction board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.214), 3-3-97) 
Sec. 10-440. - Court review. 
    Any person, having a legitimate interest in the outcome of an appeal, shall have the right to apply to the county circuit court for review of a decision of the construction board of appeals in accordance with the applicable state law and court rules. 
(Ord. No. 2-97, § 1(11.215), 3-3-97) 
Secs. 10-441-10-460. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Moving of oversized and overweight objects, § 70-48. 

Sec. 10-461. - License required to engage in business. 
    No person shall engage in the business or occupation of moving buildings or structures along, through or upon the public rights-of-way of this city without having first applied for and obtained a license to engage in such business or occupation in the manner provided in this article. Application for such license shall be made upon forms to be furnished by the city clerk and shall be accompanied by the fees as provided by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 11.71) 
Sec. 10-462. - Bond and policy of insurance required for license. 
(a)  An applicant for a license under this article shall deposit with the city clerk a surety bond, with a surety company authorized to do business in the state as surety, in the amount as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. Such bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful observance by the applicant, his agents, servants and employees, of all the rules and regulations imposed by the city relating to the business or occupation of moving buildings and the payment of all sums or charges accruing to the city by reason of any work or services performed by the city or any of its departments on behalf of the applicant in connection with the moving of any building. 
(b)  An applicant for a license under this article shall indemnify and reimburse the city for all loss, injury or damage to any tree, pavement, street, sewer, water main, sidewalk, awning, wire, fire alarm, telegraph, telephone or other pole or wires and cables or any other property of the city of any nature whatsoever, which loss, injury or damage arises out of, or by reason of, the carrying on of the activity of building mover by the applicant. For purposes of so indemnifying and reimbursing the city, the applicant shall furnish an insurance policy which shall provide for insurance against injuries or damages to the city or its property. Such insurance shall insure the applicant and the city against the liabilities which this section requires the applicant to indemnify the city against. 
(c)  The applicant for a license under this article shall further defend, indemnify and hold harmless the city its officers, agents and employees from any and all claims and liabilities of any nature whatsoever which claims or liabilities arise out of, or by reason of, the carrying on of the activity of the applicant as a building mover. The applicant shall furnish to the city clerk a duplicate policy of insurance, insuring the applicant and the city against any and all legal liability by reason of any damage to persons or property arising out of the applicant's activities as a building mover. Such insurance shall further insure the applicant and the city against any and all legal liability to the city by reason of the obligations imposed by this section with reference to damage to property of the city or claims or liabilities as set forth in this section. The policy of insurance shall be in the amounts as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. Such policy of insurance shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney as to compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 3-93, § 1(11.72), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 10-463. - Permit required to move building. 
    No person shall move any building, any exterior dimension of which shall exceed eight feet in width, eight feet in length, or ten feet in height, without first obtaining a permit for the moving of such building and paying the fees as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(11.73), 2-15-93) 
Sec. 10-464. - Application for permit and building requirements. 
(a)  Any person requiring a moving permit pursuant to section 10-463 shall file an application with the building inspector which shall contain the following information concerning the building to be moved: 
(1)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant, general contractor, mover and any other person responsible for moving the building and bringing the building up to code. 
(2)  The address and legal description of the present location of the building and also for the site to which the building is to be moved. 
(3)  Photographs of each side of the building at its present location. 
(4)  Scale drawings of the exterior building elevations, an interior floor plan, completed foundation plan and any other information as may be required by the building inspector and a scaled drawing of the location of the building on the new site and any other information concerning the location as may be required by the building inspector. 
(b)  The following requirements shall apply to any building to be moved: 
(1)  The building shall conform with the architectural design of the other buildings in the area within 500 feet of the site so as not to devalue other homes within 500 feet. The building inspector shall make this determination. 
(2)  Any building to be moved shall be structurally sound. 
(3)  Within 60 days after the move has been completed, the building shall be completed for occupancy including, but not limited to, drive approach, grading and foundation with basement. Seeding or sod shall be completed within 60 days, or as soon as the weather permits. 
(4)  A bond, cash surety, irrevocable letter of credit from a recognized financial institution or other form of guarantee acceptable to the city, other than the mover's bond, shall be required in an amount equal to the estimated costs of bringing the building up to any codes of the city after it has been moved. Such estimates shall be submitted to the building inspector prior to the issuance of a permit. The city attorney shall approve the bond or other surety prior to the issuance of the permit. 
(5)  All applications shall be forwarded to the traffic engineer for an approval of the proposed street or public route to be taken and to the park superintendent for a report as what effect the proposed move would have on any trees, shrubs and other plantings of the city, together with any costs of trimming, removing or replacing the same, together with a recommendation as to the proposed move. All applicants shall deposit with the city a minimum of $1,000.00 from which all actual costs incurred by the city shall be deducted following the proposed move. 
(6)  Permit fees shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3-93, § 3(11.74), 2-15-93; Ord. No. 14-00, §§ 1, 2, 9-5-00) 
Sec. 10-465. - Rules imposed upon permit holders. 
    The person to whom a permit to move a building has been issued under this article shall comply with the following rules: 
(1)  He shall follow the route prescribed in the permit. 
(2)  He shall observe all rules, regulations and provisions of this article. 
(3)  He shall move such building with all dispatch and in such a manner as to cause the least obstruction or interference with public travel. 
(4)  If it shall be necessary to leave such building in any street overnight, he shall place sufficient red lights on the building to warn passersby of its location and shall keep such lights in operating condition throughout the night. 
(Code 1983, § 11.75) 
Sec. 10-466. - Removal of cables and wires. 
    If it shall be found that the moving of any building will result in contact with the lines, wires or cables of any public utility, the applicant for such permit shall forthwith notify such public utility that such lines, wires or cables may interfere with the movements of such building and shall arrange with such public utility for removal and restoration of such lines, wires or cables. 
(Code 1983, § 11.76) 
Sec. 10-467. - Removal or trimming of trees. 
    If it shall be found that the moving of any building will result in contact with any trees located in a public place to such an extent as to require the trimming or removal of the trees, then the applicant for such permit shall arrange for such trimming and removal with the park superintendent and shall pay the cost of such trimming or the cost of removal and the replacement thereof. 
(Code 1983, § 11.77) 
Sec. 10-468. - Appeals for variances. 
    Any person making an application for a permit to move a building, who may be denied such permit by the building inspector, may file an appeal in writing to the board of appeals created and existing under the zoning provisions of this Code. Such appeal shall be taken in the same manner as if made from the building inspector under the zoning provisions of this Code. Upon conducting a hearing, the board of appeals may grant a variance from the strict application of the provisions of this article, provided the board shall find that all of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The variance desired arises from a peculiar condition not ordinarily existing and due to the character of the premises or the nature or operation of the business conducted thereon. 
(2)  The variance desired is not against the public interest and is consistent with public safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(3)  The granting of a permit for a variance will not adversely affect the rights of owners of adjacent property. 
(4)  The strict application of the terms of this article will result in imposing an unnecessary hardship upon the owner of the property concerned. 
The decision of the board shall be final on the date given, and the building inspector shall issue a permit in accordance with such decisions. The board may impose such conditions as it deems necessary to protect persons or property. 
(Code 1983, § 11.78) 
Secs. 10-469-10-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 10-501. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private means not open to the public, is not publicly owned, nor is otherwise regulated by the state either by statute or by rules or regulations of one of its administrative bodies. 
    Swimming pool means any artificially constructed, nonportable pool capable of being used for swimming or bathing and having a depth of two feet or more at any point. 
(Code 1983, § 11.61) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-502. - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall construct or install a private swimming pool within the city unless a permit has been obtained in the manner prescribed in section 10-503. 
(Code 1983, § 11.62) 
Sec. 10-503. - Same-Fees; application. 
    The permit as required by section 10-502 shall be applied for and obtained from the building inspector before any construction shall begin on such pool. Such application shall be accompanied by a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the swimming pool. No permit shall be issued until such plans and specifications have been approved by the building inspector. Before any swimming pool may be used, a final inspection must be made by and approval obtained from the building inspector. 
(Code 1983, § 11.63) 
Sec. 10-504. - Location and installation regulations. 
    Every pool constructed or installed pursuant to this article shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No swimming pool shall be nearer than six feet from side or rear lot lines or from any house, building or residence. 
(2)  All wiring and lighting shall be installed in accordance with methods and materials approved by the electrical inspector according to the applicable Michigan Electrical Code, Michigan Building Code or Michigan Residential Code. 
(3)  There shall be no cross connection between the city water supply and any other source of water supply for such pool. The line from the city water supply to the pool shall be protected against backflow of polluted water by means of an air gap and shall discharge at least six inches above the maximum high-water level of the makeup tank of the pool. 
(4)  The drain line for the pool may be connected by the city sewer system under the following conditions: 
a.  A pool drain shall be connected to the storm sewer where one is available. 
b.  Where a storm sewer is not available, the pool drain may be connected to a sanitary sewer or a combined sewer upon approval by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
(5)  The pool shall be constructed so that all scum, splash and deck water shall not return to the pool except through a filter system. 
(6)  The pool shall be kept free at all times of floating material, sediment and debris either by an automatic surface skimmer, scum gutter or by some other means approved by the city. 
(7)  The entire recirculating system shall be capable of filtering and recirculating the entire volume content of the pool during a 12-hour period. The rate of application of pool water on the filters shall not be greater than three gallons per minute per square foot of filter area. 
(8)  Provisions shall be made for positive germicidal or bacterial control by the use of chlorine, bromine or such other disinfecting materials approved by the health officer. Such disinfecting materials shall be applied to the pool water at a uniform rate. Provision shall be made for the adjustment of such application so that the germicidal or bacterial protection of the water in the pool is kept equal to a standard of 0.5 part per million to 1.0 part per million chlorine residual. Testing devices capable of accurately measuring such residual shall be provided. 
(9)  All swimming pools now or hereafter constructed shall be completely enclosed by a barrier which shall comply with the applicable standards as required in the Michigan Building Code and Michigan Residential Code in effect at the time of issuance of the permit. 
(10)  Lights used to illuminate a private swimming pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
(11)  The city manager shall have the authority to waive subsection (1) of this section after a discussion of the proposed waiver with the adjoining property owners and after making a finding that the waiver will not adversely effect the property owners. 
(Code 1983, § 11.64; Ord. No. 12-93, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 9-03, §§ 8, 9, 5-19-03) 
Cross reference- Cross connections, § 86-91 et seq. 
Sec. 10-505. - Inspection. 
    The city shall have the right at any reasonable hour to inspect any swimming pool for the purpose of determining that the provisions of this article are being met. 
(Code 1983, § 11.65) 
Chapter 14 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes:
