Editor's note- Ord. No. 4-14, adopted March 17, 2014, repealed div. 2, which consisted of §§ 14-231-14-246, pertained to amusement machines, and derived from the 1983 Code; Ord. No. 6-96, adopted April 1, 1996; and Ord. No. 14-02, adopted August 19, 2002. 

Secs. 14-231-14-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CARNIVALS 

Sec. 14-276. - Permit required, application requirements; bond; insurance. 
    Any person, firm, association, or corporation desiring to operate an outdoor carnival open to the public within the city shall file an application on a form provided by the city clerk giving the name, location of site, length of stay, insurance, number and type of amusements and operations, a security plan subject to the approval of the chief of police, a site plan including general location of rides and other attractions, a parking plan, and such other information as may be required by the city. All permits shall specify the location, dates of the carnival and such other information pertinent to the operation of the carnival as determined by the city. The carnival operator must include with its application the written approval of all carnival sponsors and the landowner of the proposed carnival site. The application must be accompanied by the payment of all fees, bonds, and evidence of insurance as required by this article. The required bond shall be furnished in cash or in such other form acceptable to and approved by the city attorney. Evidence of liability insurance shall be provided in a form acceptable to and approved by the city attorney and shall name the city as an additional insured. 
    The application and all information required shall be submitted to the city clerk at least 30 days before the first day of the carnival. 
(Code 1983, § 80.235; Ord. No. 10-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 14-277. - Duration and number of permits. 
    The maximum duration of all permits is ten days. No more than three carnivals per year shall be permitted at the same location within the city. A minimum ten days interval is required between carnivals on a site. 
(Code 1983, § 80.251; Ord. No. 15-02, § 1, 8-19-02) 
Sec. 14-278. - Hours. 
    All outdoor carnivals shall not open before 10:00 a.m., and shall close no later than 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday, 11:00 p.m. on Friday and Saturday. 
(Code 1983, § 80.252; Ord. No. 15-02, § 2, 8-19-02) 
Sec. 14-279. - Cleaning of site. 
    The immediate vicinity of all outdoor carnivals shall be kept reasonably clean and free of debris at all times. At the end of any outdoor carnival, the carnival owner and operator must clear the site of all papers, litter and other debris, and return the site to its original condition. 
(Code 1983, § 80.253) 
Sec. 14-280. - Location. 
    Outdoor carnivals may only be located within areas zoned B-2 (business district-general), B-3 (business district-planned shopping) and Form Based Code. All outdoor carnivals shall be conducted at least 300 feet from any residential property line, except for any carnival where all rides are designated for children of 12 years or less in age. All outdoor carnivals must be located at a site containing no less than four acres of vacant area suitable for the carnival and parking. No part of any carnival shall obstruct or impede in any way the full and instant use of any designated fire lane, fire hydrant, sprinkler system connection or valve, or any other equipment or space intended for emergency use. 
(Code 1983, § 80.254; Ord. No. 15-02, § 3, 8-19-02; Ord. No. 16-14, § 1, 7-21-14) 
Sec. 14-281. - Security plan. 
    The security plan required in section 14-276 of this division shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  At least two persons on duty at all times, who are clearly identifiable as security, and who have no other duties in the operation of the carnival. Security personnel may include volunteers from the sponsoring organization. 
(2)  Immediately available means of communication with the police department for each such security person. 
(3)  Provision of 24-hour contact information for a representative of the carnival. 
(Code 1983, § 80.255; Ord. No. 10-04, § 2, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 14-282. - Waiver of division restrictions. 
    Any of the restrictions of this division may be waived by the city council if the operator or sponsor is a nonprofit religious, fraternal, school or community organization that has been established in the city for at least five years, and the waiver is deemed to be in the best interests of the city. The city council may consider a waiver for any other operator or sponsor if all or a portion of the proceeds from the carnival are donated to a nonprofit, religious, fraternal, school or community organization. 
(Ord. No. 10-04, § 3, 6-21-04) 
Secs. 14-283-14-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4 - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-13, adopted July 15, 2013, repealed div. 4 in its entirety. Former div. 4 consisted of §§ 14-311-14-314, 14-341-14-349, pertained to outdoor assemblies and derived from the 1983 Code. 

Secs. 14-311-14-375. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - POOL HALLS 

Sec. 14-376. - Findings of fact. 
    The city council does hereby make the following findings of fact: The city council has studied the problems related to the operation of pool halls within the city. Information has been furnished to it by the chief of police. A public hearing was held to permit anyone to present evidence and offer testimony. The city council finds that it is necessary to regulate pool halls within the city because there have been numerous violations of the law in and around pool halls, thereby creating an unreasonable burden on the city of police protection and surveillance. 
(Code 1983, § 80.160) 
Sec. 14-377. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pool hall means any place open to the public where three or more pool, billiard, snooker or any other similar type table or combination thereof are offered for play by any person, whether for consideration or not. 
(Ord. No. 395, § 1, 3-6-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-378. - Gambling. 
    Gambling or betting of any kind is prohibited in any pool hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.163) 
Sec. 14-379. - License required. 
    No person shall operate any pool hall within the city unless a license therefor has been obtained as required. 
(Code 1983, § 80.162) 
Sec. 14-380. - Responsibility of owner. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or operator of any pool hall to maintain order and to provide a sufficient number of employees for direct supervision of the pool hall and any parking lot as may be adjacent to the pool hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.164) 
Sec. 14-381. - Patrons under 16 years. 
    No person under 16 years of age shall be allowed within the building of a pool hall unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(Code 1983, § 80.165) 
Sec. 14-382. - Identification to be shown by persons under 21 years. 
    All persons under the age of 21 years must furnish identification as to such age. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or operator of the pool hall to ascertain the exact age of any person permitted within the building of any pool hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.166) 
Sec. 14-383. - Loitering. 
    Loitering in or about the building or any of the area surrounding the building which area is owned or leased by the pool hall owner or operator is hereby prohibited. No owner or operator of any pool hall shall permit such loitering. 
(Code 1983, § 80.167) 
Sec. 14-384. - Police investigation. 
    The owner and operator of any pool hall shall be subject to the same routine police investigation and approval where necessity in the same manner as established for those persons having any tavern, class C, specially designated distributors (SDD) or specially designated merchant (SDM) licenses. 
(Code 1983, § 80.168) 
Sec. 14-385. - View of inside of premises. 
    All pool halls shall be constructed so that the interior of the building may be readily observed from the outside. Drapes for any windows shall be kept open during the time that such business is open to the public or in operation. 
(Code 1983, § 80.169) 
Sec. 14-386. - Reporting of violations. 
    All violations of any sections of this Code or state statutes which occur within the pool hall building or on the premises shall be reported by the owner or operator of the pool hall to the police department in writing within 24 hours after such violation has occurred. 
(Code 1983, § 80.170) 
Secs. 14-387-14-410. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PUBLIC DANCES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Public dances, MCL 750.141, 750.464a, MSA 28.336, 28.719(1). 

Sec. 14-411. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public dance means a dance held in a public dancehall to which the general public of the age of 17 years and above is admitted. 
    Public dancehall means any place where dancing is held or permitted and to which the general public is admitted. 
(Code 1983, § 10.45) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-412. - License-Required; application contents. 
    No person shall conduct a public dance or operate a public dancehall in the city without having first obtained the appropriate license therefor. Application for a public dancehall shall show the following: 
(1)  Location and description. 
(2)  Sanitary facilities. 
(3)  Ventilation. 
(4)  Entrances and exits. 
(5)  Type of operation. 
(6)  Owners with their names, addresses and business occupations. 
(7)  Proposed modifications or changes to be made in the building. 
(8)  Such other information as may be requested by the chief of police or the building official of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 10.46) 
Sec. 14-413. - Same-Review; grant or denial. 
    The application shall be filed with the city clerk, and copies shall be furnished to the chief of police and the building official. The chief of police shall review the application and shall determine whether or not the owners or proposed operators of the dancehall are of good moral character; namely, whether or not any one of them has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. The building official shall review the application, visit the dancehall premises and shall determine whether or not the dancehall meets the requirements of any applicable provisions of this Code, including BOCA. The chief of police and the building official shall file their reports with the city manager, who shall submit his recommendation to the city council based upon such reports. The city council shall review such report and shall either grant or deny the license. If the license is denied, it shall establish the reasons therefor in its resolution. 
(Code 1983, § 10.47) 
Sec. 14-414. - Police authority. 
    Whenever the licensee, its officers, agents or employees, permits any disorderly or illegal conduct or violates any provisions of this Code or any other applicable laws, rules and regulations, which violations are or could become a public nuisance, the police department shall have the authority to prevent or stop any dance being conducted at the licensee's place of business or such other place and to suspend the license until at such time as the situation has been permanently corrected. Failure to correct the situation for which the license was suspended or the dance stopped shall be grounds for revocation of the license. 
(Code 1983, § 10.48) 
Sec. 14-415. - Closing hours; age of participants. 
    No person under the age of 17 years shall be permitted in a dancehall. All dances shall stop at 12:30 a.m., with the dancehall to be closed at 1:00 a.m. 
(Code 1983, § 10.49) 
Sec. 14-416. - Security. 
(a)  For each dance, the licensee shall provide security in the following numbers: 
(1)  0-50, 1 security officer; 
(2)  50-100, 2 security officers; and 
(3)  For each additional 150 or fraction thereof, one additional security officer. 
(b)  The names and numbers of the security personnel shall be furnished to the police department the last two days before each dance. 
(Code 1983, § 10.50) 
Sec. 14-417. - License review. 
    Each dancehall license permit shall be reviewed on an annual basis, with reports to be submitted by the police chief and building official to the city manager with their recommendations. The city manager, after reviewing such reports, shall renew or rescind the license in the same manner as for a new license. 
Sec. 14-418. - Exception. 
    No license shall be required for any nonprofit corporation to conduct a public dance. Such dances shall be by permit only granted by the city manager. Such applications for a dance shall be presented to the city manager for his review and approval and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address. 
(2)  Date of incorporation. 
(3)  Interested party. 
(4)  Date, place and time of dance. 
(5)  Charges. 
(6)  Purposes for which the money raised from the dance is to be used. 
(7)  Persons who will be in charge. 
(8)  Such other information as may be required by the city manager. 
The city manager shall grant or deny the application. If such application is denied, it shall be on a basis that such dance would be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare and reasons therefor shall be given in the denial. All school dances are exempted from compliance with this section. 
Secs. 14-419-14-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS AND FACILITIES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 19-18, effective Dec. 3, 2018, amended art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VI pertained to the same subject matter, consisted of §§ 14-451-14-453, and derived from Ord. No. 21-14, adopted Nov. 17, 2014. 

Sec. 14-451. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  IHRA means the Industrial Hemp Research Act, 2014 PA 547, MCL 286.841 et seq. 
(b)  Marihuana establishment means that term as defined in the MRTMA. 
(c)  Marihuana facility means that term as defined in the MMFLA. 
(d)  MMFLA means the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act, 2016 PA 281, MCL 333.27101 et seq. 
(e)  MMMA means the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, 2008 IL 1, MCL 333.26421 et seq. 
(f)  MRTMA means the Michigan Regulation and Taxation of Marihuana Act, 2018 IL 1, MCL 333.27951 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 19-18, § 1, 12-3-18) 
Sec. 14-452. - Marihuana establishments and facilities prohibited. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 6 of the MRTMA marihuana establishments are prohibited within the boundaries of the city. 
(b)  Marihuana facilities are prohibited within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 19-18, § 1, 12-3-18) 
Sec. 14-453. - Rights unaffected by article. 
(a)  Except as specifically provided in section 14-452 prohibiting marihuana establishments, this article shall not affect the rights or privileges of any individual or other person under the MRTMA. 
(b)  This article does not affect the rights or privileges of a marihuana facility outside the boundaries of the city to engage in activities within the boundaries of the city that it is allowed to engage in under the MMFLA within a municipality that has not authorized marihuana facilities to operate within the municipality. 
(c)  This article does not affect any rights or privileges of registered qualifying patients or registered primary caregivers under the MMMA or the MMFLA. 
(d)  This article does not affect any rights or privileges of any individual or other person under the IHRA. 
(e)  This article does not affect any rights or privileges of any individual or other person under any other federal or state law, rule or regulation related to the medical use of marihuana. 
(Ord. No. 19-18, § 1, 12-3-18) 
Sec. 14-454. - Review. 
    The city council shall review this article and the prohibitions in section 14-452 following the state's promulgation of rules pursuant to the MRTMA, but such a review shall occur not later than June 30, 2020. 
(Ord. No. 19-18, § 1, 12-3-18) 
Secs. 14-455-14-485. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GASOLINE STATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-486. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bay, service means an area within the principal building for the servicing or repair of motor vehicles. 
    Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls for the shelter, enclosure or protection of persons, animals or property. 
    Building, accessory means a subordinate building, the use of which is customarily incidental to that of the principal building on the same lot. 
    Building, principal means a building in which is conducted the main or principal use of the lot on which the building is situated. 
    Filling station, gasoline station or service station means a structure, building or premises, or any portion thereof, where a flammable fluid or other petroleum product is stored or housed for the for automobiles on the premises, or where motor vehicles are serviced and repaired. 
    Lot means one or more lots, or parcels of land, occupied by one or more principal and accessory buildings, used in common for the operation of the business located thereon, including any open space as may be required by use or by this article. 
    Self-service filling station means a filling station where the customer of the flammable fluid actively engages in the dispensing of the flammable fluid. 
    Structures means any combination of materials, including buildings constructed and erected, which requires location on the ground or attachment to any other object having a location on the ground including, but not limited to, signs, gasoline pumps, hoists, fences, lightpoles, air pumps and gauges, and nonmovable property employed in the operation of a gasoline station. 
(Code 1983, § 80.51) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-487. - General requirements. 
    The following requirements shall apply to all gasoline stations: 
(1)  All gasoline stations shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the regulations of this article. 
(2)  All material, merchandise and products other than liquid fuel shall be stored or housed within the principal and accessory buildings. 
(3)  Refuse and trash may be stored outside the principal building but shall be kept within a completely enclosed or screened area. 
(4)  All lubrication, repair and servicing equipment shall be entirely enclosed within the principal building. 
(5)  Gasoline or other inflammable mixtures shall not be used for any type of cleaning. 
(6)  All repair work shall be done within the principal or accessory building. 
(7)  No operator shall permit the storage of automobiles for a period in excess of 24 hours unless the vehicle is parked within a building. 
(8)  No person shall use the premises for the sale or rental of new or used vehicles unless licensed to do so. 
(9)  No person shall deposit, or cause to be deposited, upon the streets or roadways adjacent to the premises, any snow, ice or other debris from the premises. 
(10)  Wherever a gasoline station is erected on a lot abutting upon residentially zoned or residentially used property, a barrier shall be provided to separate the gasoline filling station premises from the residential property. 
(11)  Any exterior lighting used on the premises shall be so arranged and so shaded as not to shine or reflect into residential buildings and areas. There shall be no revolving or flashing lights. 
(12)  All driveways, service areas and parking areas shall be paved either by asphalt or cement, and shall be graded and drained so as to prevent accumulation of surface water. 
(13)  Heating plants shall be located so that there is not an open flame lower than eight feet above floor level. The regulation shall apply to hot water heaters and any other appliances in a service station which have an open flame. 
(14)  Any sewer designed to carry carwash and greasing room wastes shall be connected only to a sanitary sewer, when such sewer is available. The sewer shall be provided with adequate traps to intercept sand, grease and oils, which traps shall be kept clean at all times. When no sanitary sewer is available, all carwash and greasing room wastes shall be disposed of by disposal systems of such type and design as shall be approved by the building inspector. 
(Code 1983, § 80.55) 
Sec. 14-488. - Self-service stations. 
    Self-service stations shall comply with the following requirements in addition to the other requirements of this article: 
(1)  If there is at least one qualified attendant on duty while the station is open to the public, an approved self-service dispensing device of the remote controlled type may be employed in a manner that, when a fueling operation is completed, the dispenser is deactivated at the emergency control position or dispenser location and may be reactivated only at the emergency control position. 
(2)  The self-service station attendant's primary function shall be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of class I, II and III liquids while the liquids are being dispensed. It is the responsibility of the attendant to prevent the dispensing of a class I liquid into a portable container which does not comply with state law and Rule 105 of the Flammable Liquid Regulations of the Michigan State Police, Fire Marshal Division, being particularly those promulgated and adopted on May 28, 1963. 
(3)  If the dispensing of a class I, II or III liquid at a self-service station open and available to the public is by a person other than the service station attendant, the nozzle shall be an approved automatic closing type without a hold-open latch. Such liquid classifications are defined in the Flammable Liquid Regulations of the Michigan State Police, Fire Marshal Division, being particularly those regulations promulgated and adopted on May 28, 1963. 
(4)  Approved emergency controls shall be installed at a location not more than 100 feet from a dispenser. The attendant or supervisor shall remain at the emergency controls during the dispensing of a class I, II or III liquid. 
(5)  Permanent signs and placards printed in not less than one-half-inch block letters on a contrasting background shall be posted at each self-service dispensing device and in full view so as to give complete and clear instructions for its operation. 
(6)  Permanent signs and placards printed in not less than three-inch block letters on a contrasting background shall be conspicuously posted in full view so as to: 
a.  Prohibit smoking anywhere on station property within 15 feet of any motor fueling operations; and 
b.  Require the vehicle engine to be shut off before the fueling operation may commence. 
(7)  Approved two-way electronic voice communications shall be provided between the emergency control position and the self-service dispensing locations. 
(8)  Self-service dispensers shall not occupy the same pump island as the attended dispensers. Pump islands with self-service dispensers shall be separated from all other attended dispenser pump islands by a distance of not less than ten feet. 
(9)  Where the vehicle design characteristic, or the position or location of a vehicle would obscure the supervisor's view of the fueling operation, or the volume of sales would otherwise prevent reasonable supervision of the fueling operation, there shall be additional precaution or equipment, or both, so as to provide an unobstructed view. 
(10)  A self-service station shall be equipped with fire extinguishers of the ten BC rating or more. 
(11)  Each supervisor or attendant shall supervise the fueling of no more than nine vehicles. If more than nine vehicles are to be fueled, there shall be an additional attendant or supervisor on duty for each additional nine fueling operations or fractions thereof. Sufficient safeguards in the form of barriers or other devices shall be provided to ensure that no more than the prescribed number of fueling operations may be carried out at one time as determined by the number of supervisors or attendants on duty. 
(12)  Gasoline dispensing units shall be placed no closer than ten feet from a door, door opening, window or window opening. 
(13)  Electrical wiring shall conform to the National Electrical Code as provided in this city Code. 
(14)  Test holes shall be provided so that gas leakage may be detected. 
(15)  If the control booth is in a hazardous area, heating of the booth shall be of an approved type. 
(Code 1983, § 80.57) 
Secs. 14-489-14-510. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 14-511. - Required. 
    No person shall operate a gasoline station or service station or self-service station within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article and paying the fees as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.52) 
Sec. 14-512. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Application for a new license to operate a gasoline station or service station shall be filed with the city clerk upon forms furnished by him. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Location. 
(2)  Name and address of the owner. 
(3)  Name and address of the person to be in charge. 
(4)  Site and plot plan. 
(5)  Hours and days of operation. 
(6)  Location of storage tanks. 
(7)  Location of driveways. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.53) 
Sec. 14-513. - Approval. 
    Upon receipt of the application, the clerk shall forward copies of the application to the director of inspectional services, electrical inspector, fire chief and such other department heads as may be required for approval as to conform with applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1983, § 80.54) 
Sec. 14-514. - Termination or suspension. 
    Any license issued under this article may be terminated or suspended for the same reason and in the same manner as specified in this chapter. 
(Code 1983, § 80.56) 
Secs. 14-515-14-540. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HEALTH CLUBS AND MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-16, adopted June 20, 2016, amended art. VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. VIII pertained to the same subject matter, consisted of §§ 14-541-14-545, 14-576-14-578,14-580-14-583, and derived from the 1983 Code; and Ord. No. 20-99, adopted Nov. 15, 1999. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 14-541. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Health club means any establishment which offers service in the form of massage, baths, exercises, or similar services in any combination or alone to club members or to the public for a charge. 
    Massage establishment means a building, room, place or establishment, other than a regularly licensed hospital or dispensary, where body massage is regularly practiced on the human body, for other than cosmetic or beautifying purposes, with or without the use of nonpowered mechanical or bathing devices. 
    Massage therapy shall be defined as provided in section 17957 of the Michigan Public Health Code, MCL 333.17957, as amended. 
    Myomassologist means a person who offers his services for hire in the practice of massage. 
(b)  The terms "health club" and "massage establishment" shall not include: 
(1)  Hospitals, nursing homes, medical clinics, offices of a physician, surgeon, osteopath or chiropractor; 
(2)  Exercise clubs, exclusively for members without massage in any form; 
(3)  Barber shops or beauty parlors without massage in any form. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-542. - Physical establishment and sanitation standards. 
    Each health club and massage establishment shall comply with all applicable requirements for the physical establishment and sanitation standards as provided by the Kent County Health Department, the State of Michigan or any other applicable regulatory agency. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 14-543. - Inspections. 
    The premises of any health club or massage establishment shall be open for inspection at any time by the department of public safety, the city inspections department or any other department of the city or any other regulatory agency. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 14-544. - Commercial sexual activities. 
(1)  Definition. "Commercial sexual activity" shall be as defined in Section 462a of the Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.462a, as amended. 
(2)  No person shall engage in any commercial sexual activity in or about any health club or massage establishment. 
(3)  In addition to any other penalties provided by this Code or any applicable statute, any commercial sexual activity on or about the premises of a health club or massage establishment shall be grounds for revocation of the business license of the establishment by the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Secs. 14-545-15-575. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE REQUIREMENT 

Sec. 14-576. - Business license. 
    No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other business entity shall engage in the business of a health club or massage establishment without having obtained a general business license from the city for that location. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 14-577. - Massage therapist. 
(1)  No person shall engage in the practice of massage therapy without having obtained a license from the State of Michigan in accordance with the provisions of Section 17957 of the Public Health Code, MCL 333.17957, et seq., as amended. 
(2)  Any person engaging in the practice of massage therapy shall immediately provide a current copy of the license to any employee or agent of the city upon request. Failure to immediately provide the license shall subject the person to all criminal and civil penalties provided in this Code and shall be grounds for revocation of the business license as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 9-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Secs. 14-578-14-600. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - JUNK AND AUTOMOBILE YARDS 

Sec. 14-601. - License-Required. 
    No person shall allow, permit, perform or engage in the business of the dismantling, storing, wrecking, salvaging, disposing of or in any other manner keeping on any premises in the city, any junk, automobiles, inoperable machinery, vehicles or parts thereof, metal, waste, scrap or other material, which by its condition cannot reasonably be used for its original purpose, without having first obtained a license from the city clerk in the manner provided for in this chapter and such other applicable chapters of this Code and the state statutes. 
(Code 1983, § 80.81) 
Sec. 14-602. - Same-Application. 
    No license shall be granted by the city clerk until the application therefor has been approved by the mayor and referred to the police chief, building inspector and the fire chief and a report has been received by them stating that the exercise of the license applied for in the proposed location will not injure the public health, safety or welfare and that the applicant has substantially complied with federal, state and local law during the five years immediately preceding the filing of the application. 
(Code 1983, § 80.82) 
Sec. 14-603. - Fence. 
    A fence six feet in height shall be constructed and maintained so as to prevent a person from being able to see the junk automobiles or other junk material or any other contents inside the junkyard. No advertising other than that of the applicant shall be tacked, nailed or posted upon any such fence. The fence shall be kept painted and in good repair. 
(Code 1983, § 80.83) 
Sec. 14-604. - Parking and display. 
    All inoperable automobiles or parts of dismantled automobiles, shall be displayed or parked inside of fence as provided in section 14-603. 
(Code 1983, § 80.84) 
Sec. 14-605. - Burning operations. 
    The burning of wrecked or discarded automobiles or any parts thereof shall be performed only in incinerator enclosures approved for burning purposes by the fire chief or in accordance with any state law, rules or regulations. 
(Code 1983, § 80.85) 
Sec. 14-606. - Prohibited purchases. 
    No licensee under the provisions of this article shall purchase or receive any used or secondhand automobile, or any part of an automobile, from any person who is under the age of 17 years, without the written consent of his parent or guardian. No such licensee shall purchase any automobile or any part of an automobile which he has reason to believe to have been stolen. 
(Code 1983, § 80.86) 
Sec. 14-607. - Business record. 
    Each licensee under the provisions of this article shall keep a daily record of all business transactions relating to used automobiles and to parts of automobiles, which record shall include the names and the addresses of persons from whom such automobiles or parts are purchased and to whom the automobiles or parts are sold, the identity of the automobile or part by name and description, including whenever applicable, the year of manufacture, serial number, engine number, body number, and any other pertinent identification number, mark or description. Failure to keep such a record by any such licensee or by any of his agents or subordinates shall constitute a violation of this section and shall constitute sufficient grounds for the revocation of the license granted to him. The police chief shall have access to such daily records. 
(Code 1983, § 80.87) 
Secs. 14-608-14-630. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PARKING LOTS AND GARAGES 

Sec. 14-631. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage means a building, shed or enclosure, or any portion thereof in which more than five motor vehicles are intended to be and may be parked, stored, housed or kept. 
    Motor vehicle means any motor vehicle as defined by the state motor vehicle code. 
    Parking lot means any outdoor space or uncovered plot, place, lot, parcel, yard or enclosure, or any portion thereof, and where more than five motor vehicles are intended to be and may be parked, stored, housed or kept. 
(Code 1983, § 10.13) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-632. - Surfacing. 
    All parking lots, garages and accesses to and from them shall be covered and maintained with asphalt or concrete so as to eliminate any dust or other materials therefrom going on to any other property. The surface shall be designed so that there is proper drainage of water from the area. Areas on which heavy duty equipment is stored or kept shall not be required to be blacktopped or have concrete but shall be treated so as to eliminate the possibility of dust or dirt from going onto any other property. Any parking area used solely for the purpose of parking cars or other vehicles to attend noncommercial recreational activities shall not be required to be blacktopped or have concrete. Notwithstanding such provisions, any area which is within 75 feet of any public right-of-way, or private right-of-way if open to the public, shall be surfaced with asphalt or concrete unless such areas are kept landscaped with grass or other materials so as to prevent any dust or soil erosion therefrom. 
(Code 1983, § 10.32) 
Sec. 14-633. - Literature distribution. 
    No person shall distribute literature or place handbills in or upon any vehicle while the same is parked in any parking lot or garage without first having obtained permission from the owner or the person in charge thereof. 
(Code 1983, § 10.33) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parking, MCL 257.606(a)1, MSA 9.2306, (a)1. 
Sec. 14-634. - Loading or unloading. 
    The loading or unloading of passengers or drivers or vehicles across or upon a public sidewalk is prohibited. Any operator or employee who, by receiving or delivering vehicles other than within the property line of the parking lot or garage, aids or assists in blocking any sidewalk or street, shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1983, § 10.34) 
Sec. 14-635. - Powers of city manager. 
    If the city manager makes a determination that the vehicles leaving or entering a parking lot are causing or will tend to cause traffic congestion, endanger public safety or create a hazard to other vehicles or pedestrians on public property, he shall have the right to make rules and regulations as to ingress and egress from such parking lot or garage after notifying the owner or person in charge thereof, and after giving such owner or person in charge thereof a hearing as to why the rules and regulations thereof should not be enforced. 
(Code 1983, § 10.35) 
Sec. 14-636. - Speed limit. 
(a)  No person shall drive any vehicle at a speed greater than 20 miles per hour on or within any parking lot or garage. 
(b)  No person shall drive any vehicle on or within any parking lot or garage at a speed greater than that which would be reasonable and proper, having due regard to the traffic, surface and width of the parking lot or garage and other conditions then existing. 
(c)  No person shall drive any vehicle on or within any parking lot or garage without due caution and circumspection or at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger persons or property. 
(d)  No person shall drive any vehicle on or within any parking lot or garage carelessly and heedlessly in willful or wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others. 
(Code 1983, § 10.36) 
Sec. 14-637. - Driving through. 
    No person shall use any parking lot for the purpose of driving any vehicle through the lot without any intent of using the lot. Failure to stop at least once in the lot prior to reaching the point of egress shall be considered prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1983, § 10.37) 
Secs. 14-638-14-675. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PEDDLERS 

Sec. 14-676. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler or peddling means any person who travels by any means from place to place or house to house selling, offering to sell, taking or soliciting orders, for any magazines, goods, wares, merchandise, food or food products. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-677. - Creation of nuisances; cause for revocation of license. 
    No person shall operate as a peddler in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance or as to violate any existing statute, code, rule or regulation. Violation of such provisions shall be cause for revocation of any license issued. 
(Code 1983, § 10.173) 
Sec. 14-678. - License-Required. 
    No person shall be a peddler without having first obtained a license as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1983, § 10.172) 
Sec. 14-679. - Same-Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article related to peddling shall not apply to any person who is under the age of 18, or any person who is peddling for any school, charitable or religious organization. 
(Code 1983, § 10.175) 
Sec. 14-680. - Same-Display. 
    While engaged in the business of peddling, the license shall be carried on the person and, when required, shall be displayed to any police officer, employee of the city or the person with whom the peddler is dealing. 
(Code 1983, § 10.174) 
Secs. 14-681-14-700. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS 

Sec. 14-701. - Registration certificate-Required. 
    No person shall engage in a business of a precious metal or gem dealer as defined in Act No. 95 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq., MSA 19.720(1) et seq.), as amended, without having first obtained a certificate of registration from the city. 
(Code 1983, § 10.701) 
Sec. 14-702. - Same-Application. 
    Any person applying for a certificate to conduct a business of a precious metal or gem dealer shall apply to the city clerk for such certificate. Such application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and thumbprint of the applicant who shall be the dealer. 
(2)  The name under which and address at which the applicant does or plans to do business. 
(3)  The name, address and thumbprint of all agents or employees of the applicant. 
(Code 1983, § 10.702) 
Sec. 14-703. - Same-Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the application, the application shall be forwarded to the chief of police and, after review and approval by the chief of police, the city clerk shall issue the certificate. 
(Code 1983, § 10.703) 
Sec. 14-704. - Same-Fee. 
    A fee shall be paid at the time the certificate is issued as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 10.704) 
Sec. 14-705. - Additional retention period. 
    Upon receipt of written notification within the retention period of seven calendar days provided in section 5 of Act No. 95 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq., MSA 19.720(1) et seq.), as amended, any precious metal or gem dealer shall retain a precious item purchased or received for an additional seven calendar days without any form of alteration other than that required to make an accurate appraisal of its value. 
(Code 1983, § 10.705) 
Sec. 14-706. - Purchase of coins. 
    In addition to those items for which records and notification to the police are required by Act No. 95 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq., MSA 19.720(1) et seq.), as amended, any precious metal and gem dealer within the city who purchases coins of any kind, whether issued by the United States government or any foreign government, shall comply with the record and notification requirements as provided in the applicable state statutes and the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1983, § 10.706) 
Secs. 14-707-14-735. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - PUBLIC LODGING 

Sec. 14-736. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public lodginghouse means any building or structure which is kept, used or maintained as an inn, hotel, tourist home, motel or public lodginghouse, where one or more rooms are made available to transients for more than 30 days in any calendar year. 
(Code 1983, § 12.91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-737. - License-Required. 
    No person shall keep, operate or maintain any public lodginghouse in the city without having first obtained a license therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article and subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1983, § 12.92) 
Sec. 14-738. - Same-Application. 
    Application for a license under this article shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided by him and shall be accompanied by the fees as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 12.93) 
Sec. 14-739. - Inspection. 
    No license shall be issued under this article until the premises to be licensed have been inspected and approved in writing by the fire chief, the building inspector and the chief of police. Such approval may be withheld if such premises do not comply in every respect with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1983, § 12.94) 
Secs. 14-740-14-765. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-766. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Going out of business sale means any sale, whether described by such name or by any other name, such as, but not limited to: closing out sales, liquidation sales, lost our lease sales, forced to vacate sales, or any other sale held in such a manner as to imply that, upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and discontinue at the premises where the sale is conducted. 
    Goods means all goods, wares, merchandise and other personal property, excepting those in action and money. 
(Code 1983, § 80.61) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-767. - Limit on advertising. 
    No person shall advertise, or otherwise represent for sale or sell, any goods as a bankruptcy, executor's, administrator's, receiver's or trustee's sales, except pursuant to, and in compliance with, federal or state statutory authority or judicial process, or as an assignee's or insolvent sale except where there is a bona fide assignment for the benefit of creditors. 
(Code 1983, § 80.65) 
Sec. 14-768. - Effect of removal of goods. 
    The license as provided for in this chapter shall be valid only for a sale of the goods inventoried and described in the application for such license, in the manner and at the time and place set forth in the application. Any removal of the goods so inventoried and described in the application from the place of sale mentioned in the application shall cause the goods to lose their identification as an insurance, bankrupt, mortgaged, insolvent's, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's or trustee's stock of goods or a stock of goods being removed or closed out, or a stock of goods damaged by fire, smoke or water, or otherwise, and no license shall be issued for the conducting of a sale of any of such goods removed from the place described in the application, under the provisions of this article at any other places. 
(Code 1983, § 80.69) 
Sec. 14-769. - Acquisition of other goods before sale. 
    No person in contemplation of conducting an insurance, bankrupt, mortgage, insolvent, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's, trustee's, removal or going out of business sale, or a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, under a license as provided in this article, shall order any goods for the purpose of selling and disposing of the goods at such sale. Any unusual purchase and additions to the stock of goods within 60 days prior to the filing of the application for a license to conduct the sale shall be presumptive evidence that the purchases and additions to stock were made in contemplation of the sale and for the purpose of selling the additions at the sale. 
(Code 1983, § 80.70) 
Sec. 14-770. - Acquisition of other goods during sale. 
    No person carrying on or conducting an insurance, bankrupt, mortgage, insolvent, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, receiver's, trustee's, removal or going out of business sale, or sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water to otherwise, under a license as provided in this article shall add, during the continuance of the sale, any goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in his original application for the license. No goods shall be sold at or during the sale, except the goods described and inventoried in the original application. Every addition of goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in the application and each sale of goods not inventoried and described in the application, shall constitute a separate offense under this article, and shall void any license issued to conduct a sale under this article. 
(Code 1983, § 80.71) 
Sec. 14-771. - Inapplicability of article to certain sales. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to sheriffs, constables, or other public or court officers, or to any other person or persons acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling goods, wares or merchandise in the course of their official duties. 
(Code 1983, § 80.72) 
Secs. 14-772-14-800. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 14-801. - Required. 
    No person shall advertise, represent or hold out that any sale of goods in an insurance, bankruptcy, mortgage, insolvent, assignee's, administrator's, receiver's, trustee's removal or sale, going out of business or sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, in the city unless he first obtains a license to conduct the sale from the city clerk. This section shall not apply to any sales by a person regularly engaged in insurance or salvage sale of goods, or the sale of goods which have been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, who acquired the goods for the account of others as a result of fire or other casualty. 
(Code 1983, § 80.61) 
Sec. 14-802. - Application. 
    Any applicant for a license under this article shall file an application in writing and under oath with the city clerk setting out the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner. If the owner is a partnership, corporation, firm or association, the name and the position of the individual filing such application. 
(2)  The name and style in which such sale is to be conducted, and the address where the sale is to be conducted. 
(3)  The dates and period of time during which the sale is to be conducted. 
(4)  The name and address of the person who will be in charge and responsible for the conduct of the sale. 
(5)  A full explanation with regard to the condition or necessity which is the occasion for the sale, including a statement of the descriptive nature of the sale and the reasons why the name is truthfully descriptive of the sale. If the application is for a license to conduct a going out of business sale, it shall also contain a statement that the business will be discontinued at the premises where the sale is to be conducted upon termination of the sale. If the application is for a license to conduct a sale of goods damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, it shall contain a statement as to the time, location and cause of the damage. 
(6)  A full, detailed and complete inventory of the goods that are to be sold, which inventory shall: 
a.  Itemize the goods to be sold, contain sufficient information concerning each item, including the make and brand name, if any, to clearly identify it. 
b.  List separately, any goods which were purchased during a 60-day period immediately prior to the date of making the application for the license. 
c.  Show the cost price of each item in the inventory together with the name and address of the seller of the items to the applicant, the date of the purchase, the date of the delivery of each item to the applicant and the total value of the inventory at cost. 
(7)  A statement that no goods will be added to the inventory after the application is made or during the sale and that the inventory contains no goods received on consignment. 
(8)  Such application shall be accompanied by such fee as is set by state statute and incorporated by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 80.63) 
Sec. 14-803. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the fee and the application giving fully and completely the information under oath as required by section 14-36 et seq., the city clerk may issue a license to the applicant to advertise, represent and sell the particular goods so inventoried at the time and place stated in the application and in true accordance with the provisions of this article. The license shall be issued in duplicate and shall bear a number and date of its expiration. A license issued under this article shall be granted and valid only for the sale of the inventoried goods which are the property of the licensee. The licensee shall apply only to the premises specified in the application, and it may not be transferred or assigned. If a licensee under this article is engaged in business in other locations, advertising or offering of goods on behalf of such location shall not represent or imply any participation in or cooperation with such sale at other locations. No license under this article shall be issued to any person for any of the following: 
(1)  Conduct a sale in the trade name or style of a person in whose goods the applicant for the license has acquired a right or title thereto within six months prior to the time of making an application for such a license. 
(2)  Continue a sale in the name of a licensee under this article whose goods such person acquired a right or title while such a sale is in progress. 
(3)  Conduct a sale, other than an insurance sale, a salvage sale or a sale of damaged goods, on the same premises within one year from the conclusion of a prior sale of the nature covered by this article. Subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section shall not apply to any person who has acquired a right, title or interest in goods as an heir, devisee or legatee, or pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1983, § 80.64) 
Sec. 14-804. - Renewal. 
    A license to conduct a sale issued pursuant to this article shall only be valid for a period not to exceed 30 days from the start of the sale, and the sale may be conducted only during the period set forth in the license. The license may be renewed not more than twice for a period not to exceed 30 days for each renewal, upon an affidavit of the licensee that the goods listed in the inventory have not been disposed of and that no new goods have been or will be added to the inventory previously filed pursuant to this article, by purchase, acquisition, consignment or otherwise. The application for renewal of the license shall be made not more than 13 days prior to the time of the expiration of the license and shall contain a new inventory of goods remaining on hand at the time the application for renewal is made, which new inventory shall be prepared and furnished in the same manner and form as the original inventory. No renewal shall be granted if any goods have been added to the stock listed in the inventory since the date of the issuance of the license. 
(Code 1983, § 80.66) 
Sec. 14-805. - Posting. 
    A copy of the application for a license to conduct a sale under this article, including the inventory filed herewith, shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the salesroom or place where the inventoried goods are to be sold, so that the public may be informed of the facts relating to the goods before purchasing such goods, but the copy need not show the purchase price of the goods. The duplicate copy of a license shall be attached to the front door of the premises where the sale is conducted in such a manner that it is clearly visible from the street. Any advertisement or announcement published in connection with the sale shall conspicuously show on its face the number of the license and the date of its expiration. 
(Code 1983, § 80.67) 
Sec. 14-806. - Recordkeeping. 
    The city clerk shall endorse upon the application the date of its filing. He shall keep the application as a record of his office. He shall make an abstract of the facts set forth in the application and place them in a book kept for that purpose. The book shall be indexed, contain the name of the persons asking such license, the nature of the proposed sale, the place where the sale is to be conducted, its duration, the inventory of the goods to be sold and a general statement as to where the goods came from. He shall make a notation in the book as to the issuance or refusal of the licenses applied for together with the dates of the same. The clerk shall endorse on the application the date the license is granted or refused. The application and abstract shall be prima facie evidence of all statements therein contained. 
(Code 1983, § 80.68) 
Secs. 14-807-14-830. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - RESERVED[9] 

Footnotes:
