    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be 21 years of age or over for the purpose of gaining entrance to any establishment where alcoholic liquor, beer or wine is sold for consumption on the premises. 
(Code 1983, § 10.101(64)) 
Sec. 50-353. - Same-Of another to procure alcoholic liquor or beer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any false representation as to the age of another for the purpose of procuring the sale or furnishing of any alcoholic liquor or beer to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(Code 1983, § 10.101(38)) 
Sec. 50-354. - Same-Of self to procure alcoholic liquor or beer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be 21 years of age or over for the purpose of procuring any alcoholic liquor or beer. 
(Code 1983, § 10.101(37)) 
Sec. 50-355. - Furnishing to underage person. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to give or furnish any alcoholic liquor or beer to any person under the age of 21, except under the authority of and pursuant to a direction of a duly licensed physician. 
(Code 1983, § 10.101(36)) 
Secs. 50-356-50-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CURFEW 

Sec. 50-371. - Minors under 12. 
    No minor under the age of 12 years shall loiter, idle or congregate in or on any public street, highway, alley or park between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., unless the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or some adult delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany the child. 
(Code 1983, § 10.11; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-2-94) 
State Law reference- Curfew, MCL 722.751 et seq. 
Sec. 50-372. - Minors 12 through 16 years old. 
    Minors 12 years old through 16 years old shall not loiter, idle or congregate in or on any public street, highway, alley or park between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., immediately following, except where the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or an adult delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany the minor, or where the minor is upon an errand or other legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian. 
(Code 1983, § 10.12; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 50-373. - Aiding or abetting violation of division. 
    No person of the age of 17 years or over shall assist, aid, abet, allow, permit or encourage any minor under the age of 17 years to violate the provisions of sections 50-371 and 50-372. 
(Code 1983, § 10.13; Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, 5-2-94) 
Sec. 50-374. - Responsibility of parent or guardian. 
    If any minor is in violation of either section 50-371 or 50-372, the parent and/or legal guardian of the minor shall be responsible for the costs of any police officer of the city in the enforcement of such sections, not to exceed $50.00 for the first violation. After the first violation, the costs shall not exceed $50.00, plus $25.00 for each subsequent violation, the costs to be cumulative. 
(Code 1983, § 10.14; Ord. No. 12-94, § 2, 5-2-94) 
Secs. 50-375-50-379. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TOBACCO 

Sec. 50-380. - Furnishing tobacco to minor. 
    No person shall knowingly, or upon failure to make diligent inquiry, sell or furnish tobacco products, including cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, tobacco snuff or tobacco in any other form to a person under 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 15-00, § 1, 9-18-00) 
Secs. 50-381-50-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - HEALTH CLUBS AND MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 50-400. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter a health club or massage establishment shall be defined as provided in section 14-541 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 50-401. - License required. 
(1)  Business license. No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other business entity shall engage in the business of a health club or massage establishment without having obtained a general business license from the city for that location. 
(2)  Massage therapist. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the practice of massage therapy without having obtained a license from the State of Michigan in accordance with the provisions of Section 17957 of the Public Health Code, MCL 333.17957, et seq., as amended. The practice of massage therapy shall be as defined therein and in this Code. 
(b)  Any person engaging in the practice of massage therapy shall immediately provide a current copy of the license to any employee or agent of the city upon request. Failure to immediately provide the license shall subject the person to all criminal and civil penalties provided in this Code and will be grounds for revocation of the business license as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 50-402. - Commercial sexual activity. 
(1)  "Commercial sexual activity" shall be as defined in section 462a of the Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.462a, as amended. 
(2)  No person shall engage in any commercial sexual activity as defined herein in or about any health club or massage establishment. 
(3)  No person shall allow any health club or massage establishment to be used for or allow commercial sexual activities to take place on or about the premises. 
(Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Chapter 54 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; animals, ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 50; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; trees and weeds, ch. 82.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Park facility rate schedule. 
    The rates to be charged for the use of park facilities shall be as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 8.1) 
Sec. 54-2. - Performance bond requirement. 
    Unless stated otherwise, all of the rates mentioned in section 54-1 shall be charged for the use of the park facility for each day or fraction thereof. In each case where a performance bond is required for the entire duration of the proposed activity if the performance bond, or any part thereof, is declared forfeited by the city, a subsequent performance bond shall be obtained before any park use is allowed to continue. 
(Code 1983, § 8.2) 
Sec. 54-3. - Exception to section 54-1. 
    The rates specified in section 54-1 shall not apply to any activity, project or game sponsored exclusively by the city. 
(Code 1983, § 8.3) 
Sec. 54-4. - Compliance with rules, regulations and directives. 
    All persons in, on or about any public property including, but not limited to, any public park, playground or swimming pool or area shall comply with, obey or follow any posted rule, regulations, sign or verbal directive from any city employee or city official having authority to issue such directive. Any person who shall fail to comply with, obey or follow any posted rule, regulations, sign or verbal directive from a city employee or city official having authority to issue such directive in any public park, playground or swimming pool or area may be refused admittance to such park, playground, swimming pool or area if the actions of such persons are detrimental to the operation of the park, playground, swimming pool or area or to other persons. If any person refuses to leave the park, playground, swimming pool or area, the assistance of a city police officer may be requested and such officer shall have the authority to order such person to leave the public area. Such person shall obey the order of the police officer. 
(Code 1983, § 8.4) 
Sec. 54-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 27-02, § 1, adopted Dec. 16, 2002, repealed § 54-5, which pertained to service club use of park facilities and derived from Code 1983, § 8.5. 
Sec. 54-6. - Closing of city parks. 
    All city parks shall be closed from 11:00 p.m. until 7:00 a.m. No person shall be in or upon any city park when the park is closed without specific written consent from the city specifying the time, date and number of persons who may use the park or park facilities during hours when the park is closed. The city manager, upon a determination by him that the public health, safety or welfare of the citizens is being adversely affected, may close the parks or any part of the parks immediately by placing signs for the areas to be closed. 
(Code 1983, § 8.6) 
Sec. 54-7. - Dog feces and posted areas. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of or any person having control of any dog to pick up and dispose of any feces from the dog while under his control and while in any park or other city property including, but not limited to, the sidewalks or parkways, within the city. The city may post any area within any city park or other city public property pertaining to dogs and other animals. The owner or person having control of any dog or other animal shall be responsible for complying with any such signs. 
(Ord. No. 2-94, § 1, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 54-8. - Boats in city parks. 
    The following regulations shall apply to the use of boats in city parks. 
(1)  Boats shall be limited to use on the lake at Battjes Park. 
(2)  Only nonmotorized boats not exceeding 12 feet in length shall be allowed. Such boats shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with minimum safety standards as prescribed by the appropriate regulatory agencies. No inflatable boats of any kind shall be allowed. 
(3)  Use shall be limited to daylight hours. 
(4)  Persons using boats on the lake shall be at least 13 years of age unless accompanied by an adult and shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations, including those prescribed by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources. 
(5)  Any person using a boat on the lake shall be wearing a Coast Guard approved flotation/life-saving device. 
(6)  Boats shall not be used for swimming. 
(7)  No boat launch shall be provided at the park and no boat trailers shall be allowed in the parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 14-06, § 1, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 54-9. - Signs in licensed park facilities. 
    Sponsorship signs may be allowed on athletic fields in city park facilities which are subject to a license agreement with the city as provided in this chapter, subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Signs will be limited to use by the city parks and recreation department and those organizations having a recreational facility license agreement with the city as provided in this chapter. 
(2)  Signs must be pre-approved by the city on an annual or seasonal basis depending on the nature of the organization and its programs. The city may limit the signage both by facility and quantity at any particular facility. 
(3)  Only sponsorship signs will be allowed. Product advertising or political signs are specifically prohibited. 
(4)  The licensed organization shall consult with the city parks and recreation department regarding any organization for which it seeks to place a sponsorship sign on a city facility. The city reserves the right to reject any sign or any organization deemed inappropriate for placement on a city park facility. 
(5)  Sign placement shall be as determined by the parks department. Signs shall not exceed 32 square feet in display area, shall not be permanently affixed and shall be oriented away from public streets to the greatest degree possible. All signage must be aesthetically appropriate and kept in good repair. 
(6)  Placement and removal of the signs shall be done by the licensed organization. All placements must be approved by the parks department not more than one week prior to use and shall be removed not later than one week following use of the sign. 
(7)  The city may, without notice, remove any sign which remains more than one week beyond the approved time for placement of the sign, any inappropriate or nonapproved sign or any sign which is in disrepair and poses a hazard to park patrons. The city may also remove any sign in disrepair but not posing a hazard to park patrons upon one week's notice to the licensed organization. 
(8)  In the event the city removes any sign, the licensed organization shall be responsible for the cost of removal by the city plus 25 percent. 
(9)  The city makes no guarantee, implied or otherwise, that signage approval will be automatic or continuous. It shall be the responsibility of the licensees seeking sponsorships to confirm that signage space is available and will be approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 27-06, § 1, 10-16-06) 
Secs. 54-10-54-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE AGREEMENTS FOR USE OF PARK PROPERTY 

Sec. 54-51. - Application. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the long-term use of city property or facilities used or dedicated as park property by the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05) 
Sec. 54-52. - Requirement for license. 
    Any eligible party using city park property or facilities shall be required to enter into a license agreement and/or recreational facilities agreement with the city for the use of any property dedicated or used as park property by the city. This requirement shall not apply to the temporary use of park property or facilities governed by the Parks and Recreation Department Fee Allocation Guidelines and Procedures. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05) 
Sec. 54-53. - Eligible parties. 
    The following organizations shall be eligible to use park property subject to a license agreement as provided in this article: 
(1)  Schools. 
(2)  Colleges or universities. 
(3)  State or federally recognized nonprofit or tax-exempt organizations. 
(4)  Local divisions or chapters of national organizations for recreational programs. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05) 
Sec. 54-54. - License agreement; contents. 
(1)  Terms of agreement. All license agreements shall be prepared by or approved by the city and shall include all appropriate terms for the use of the particular property, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Requirements for compliance with all local ordinances and applicable state and federal statutes. 
(b)  Nondiscrimination provisions as required by applicable state and federal statutes. 
(c)  Acceptable rules regarding participation and exclusion from participation of all eligible persons. The license shall be required to distribute those rules to all program participants in a manner acceptable to the city and shall verify that distribution upon request of the city. 
(d)  Provisions for noncompliance procedures and termination of the agreement. 
(2)  All agreements shall be approved by the city council prior to commencement of the use of the property. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05) 
Sec. 54-55. - Reporting requirements for nonprofit or nonpublic entities. 
    The following reporting requirements shall apply to all nonprofit or nonpublic organizations: 
(1)  Copies of any organizational documents, bylaws or other similar documents and any amendments thereto shall be filed with the city. 
(2)  An annual audit of financial records must be conducted. An independent audit shall be provided if requested by the city. 
(3)  Copies of appropriate financial records of the organization shall be submitted at the request of the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05) 
Sec. 54-56. - Insurance. 
    Any organization entering into a license agreement and/or recreational facilities agreement with the city shall provide liability and property damage insurance acceptable to the city naming the city as an additional insured. The coverage limits of any insurance shall be in an amount as required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 13-05, § 1, 10-17-05)

Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved garbage container means a container constructed of metal, plastic or other material which is waterproof, rodentproof and is supplied with a tight closure at all times when in use. 
    Approved incinerator and garbage grinder means an incinerator or garbage grinder which conforms in all respects to the requirements for incinerators and garbage grinders contained in this chapter. 
    Approved rubbish container means a bag, bin, box, can, barrel or other container or enclosure which is used for the temporary storage of rubbish, leaves, lawn wastes, construction debris, commercial waste materials or any other waste material which does not fall into the category of garbage which shall be of such material which is capable of preventing removal or spilling by wind or animals and which is rodentproof and verminproof. 
    Combustible rubbish means, but is not limited to, food containers other than metal or glass, waste paper, cardboard, wood crates, boxes and other combustible material, excluding garbage. 
    Construction refuse means waste materials resulting from any alterations, repairs or construction. 
    Director means the city manager or a person appointed by him. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable waste and all other organic material which is subject to decomposition. Dead animals weighing not in excess of five pounds shall be considered garbage. Animal manure and litter shall be considered garbage. Any mixture of garbage and any form of other waste which is accumulated or stored in one place or container shall be held to be garbage within the meaning of this chapter. 
    Noncombustible rubbish means, but is not limited to, all household and commercial waste materials which are not readily reduced by burning in an approved incinerator and which do not contain any garbage. 
(Code 1983, § 20.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-2. - Streets and sidewalks. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the public sidewalk includes the area between the sidewalk and the travelled portion of the street, and is deemed to be under the control of the owner or occupant. The half of any dedicated alley, private easement or private right-of-way shall be held to be under the control of the adjoining property owner or occupant. 
(Code 1983, § 20.11) 
Sec. 62-3. - Dumping. 
    No person shall dump, deposit, throw or place or allow to be placed, any garbage or rubbish on any premises, private or public, within the city, unless such garbage or rubbish is placed in and kept in approved garbage or rubbish containers. 
(Code 1983, § 20.2) 
Sec. 62-4. - Parks. 
    No person shall dispose of any garbage or rubbish in any park container unless such garbage or rubbish resulted or was generated from a picnic or other activity while using such park. 
(Code 1983, § 20.3) 
Secs. 62-5-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 62-31-62-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 62-46. - Required. 
    The owner or occupant of every dwelling unit and every commercial or industrial operation shall provide and maintain in sanitary condition on such premises, one or more approved garbage or rubbish containers. 
(Code 1983, § 20.4) 
Sec. 62-47. - Number. 
    The number and size of approved containers for garbage and rubbish on any premises shall be sufficient to keep all such material under cover or inaccessible to rodents or animals at all times. 
(Code 1983, § 20.5) 
Sec. 62-48. - Furnishing and removal-Single-family. 
    The occupant of any single-family dwelling shall be responsible for furnishing and maintaining in sanitary condition all approved containers for the temporary storage of garbage or rubbish on his premises, and for the regular removal of such material. 
(Code 1983, § 20.6) 
Sec. 62-49. - Same-Multiple-family. 
    The owner, manager or person in charge of any dwelling structure housing more than one family shall be responsible for furnishing and maintaining in sanitary condition all approved containers for the temporary storage of garbage or rubbish on any premises under his control and for the regular removal of such material. 
(Code 1983, § 20.7) 
Sec. 62-50. - Same-Commercial and industrial. 
    The owner, manager or person in charge of any commercial or industrial operation within the city shall be responsible for furnishing and maintaining in sanitary condition all approved containers for the temporary storage of garbage or rubbish on any premises under his control and for the regular removal of such material. 
(Code 1983, § 20.8) 
Sec. 62-51. - Location. 
    No person shall keep or store garbage or rubbish containers in the front yard or secondary front yard of any premises, nor in the space between the sidewalk and the street, except when placed there during the day scheduled for removal. Containers shall be removed promptly from such areas after being emptied. 
(Code 1983, § 20.9) 
Secs. 62-52-62-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REMOVAL 

Sec. 62-66. - At regular intervals. 
    All garbage and rubbish shall be removed from any premises in the city at regular intervals. No person shall allow any garbage to be stored on any property under his control for longer than a period of seven days or to allow any rubbish to be stored on any property under his control for longer than a period of 14 days. 
(Code 1983, § 20.10) 
Sec. 62-67. - Time extension. 
    If inclement weather, lack of available removal service or other conditions beyond the control of the person responsible make removal of accumulated garbage and rubbish impossible within the limits established in this division, the director shall extend as necessary the period of time allowed for removal. 
(Code 1983, § 20.12) 
Sec. 62-68. - Accumulation; notice to remove; lien on property. 
    No person shall allow any garbage or rubbish to accumulate on any vacant or occupied property under the person's control. If any garbage or rubbish is placed or left on property under his control, it shall immediately be removed. If such material is not so removed within a time limit established by the director, the city may remove such material and the cost of such removal shall be assessed against the property as a tax lien. 
(Code 1983, § 20.13) 
Secs. 62-69-62-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMBUSTIBLE WASTE 

Sec. 62-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act 641 Plan means the county solid waste management plan approved by the county board of commissioners and by the director of the state department of natural resources, pursuant to the requirements and provisions of Act No. 641 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1978 (MCL 299.401 et seq., MSA 13.29), as amended, and any amendments thereto adopted in accordance with such act. 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, refuse, wastewater, sludge or other combustible materials. 
    Board of public works means the county board of public works established pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 185 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq., MSA 5.570 et seq.), as amended. 
    Combustible waste means solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Combustible waste shall include: garbage; combustible rubbish, including but not limited to paper, cardboard, cartons, wood, boxes, rags, cloth, bedding, leather, grass, leaves and brush, yard trimmings; tree limbs, timber, logs, stumps six inches or less in diameter; carpeting, and combustible construction and demolition debris; and any other solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Combustible waste shall exclude: noncombustible solid waste, such as ashes, noncombustible rubbish, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, municipal and industrial sludges, animal waste, pathological and biological waste, asbestos and asbestos waste products, explosives, radioactive materials, appliances, concrete rubble, noncombustible construction and demolition debris, rock, gravel and earthen materials, automobiles, trailers, equipment wire and cable; all waste other than solid waste (such as hazardous waste, site-separated materials and source-separated materials); and any other waste that is predominantly noncombustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. 
    Commercial operation date means the date when the MBI has been completed and tested and is, in the sole opinion of the county, ready for full commercial operation. 
    County means the County of Kent, Michigan, acting by and through its board of commissioners or its department of public works. 
    Disposal site means any of the following: a solid waste transfer facility; a single incinerator having an average daily design capacity exceeding 50 tons of solid waste per day or two or more incinerators located at one site under the control of one person and having an aggregate average daily design capacity exceeding 150 tons of solid waste per day; a sanitary landfill; a solid waste processing plant; or any other solid waste handling or disposal facility utilized in the disposal of solid waste. 
    Garbage means rejected food wastes, including waste accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, used or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in, or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable. 
    Hazardous waste means hazardous waste as defined in Act No. 64 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1979 (MCL 299.501 et seq., MSA 13.30 et seq.), as amended, from time to time, and as identified in administrative rules promulgated from time to time pursuant to such act by the director of the state department of natural resources. 
    MBI means the mass-burn energy-generating incinerator to be constructed by or on behalf of, or available by contract or lease with, the county within the City of Grand Rapids in accordance with the Act 641 Plan. 
    Premises means any enclosed area used for residential, commercial, or industrial purposes, separately or in combination, to which a separate street address, postal address or box, tax roll description, or other similar identification has been assigned to or is in use by a person having control of the area. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste, excluding ashes, consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste including, but not limited to, paper, cardboard, metal containers, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, demolished building materials or litter of any kind that may be a detriment to the public health and safety. 
    Site of generation means any premises in or on which solid waste is generated by any person. 
    Site-separated materials means recyclable materials including, but not limited to, bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush and yard trimmings that are separated from solid waste after collection from a site of generation by the city, a waste hauler or the operators of a disposal site to which it is delivered. 
    Solid waste means garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, street cleanings, municipal and industrial sludges, solid commercial and solid industrial waste, and animal waste; however, this definition shall not include hazardous waste, site-separated materials, source-separated materials, human body waste, liquid or other waste regulated by statute, ferrous or nonferrous scrap directed to a scrap metal processor or to a reuser of ferrous or nonferrous products and slag or slag products directed to a slag processor or to a reuser of slag or slag products. 
    Source-separated materials means recyclable materials including, but not limited to, bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush and yard trimmings that are separated from solid waste prior to the collection of solid waste from a site of generation. 
    Tipping fee means the fee established by the board of public works to be charged upon delivery of combustible waste to the MBI. 
    Waste hauler means any person engaged, in whole or in part, in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of combustible waste within the city. 
(Code 1983, § 20.201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-87. - Scope of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall govern the collection, transportation, delivery and disposal of combustible waste by waste haulers. In the event of any conflict or inconsistency between this article and any other provisions of this chapter, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(Code 1983, § 20.202) 
Sec. 62-88. - License required for engaging in business of collection and disposal. 
    Commencing as of the commercial operation date of the MBI, no person shall engage in the business of collection, transportation, delivery or disposal of combustible waste within the city without having obtained a license from the city as provided in section 62-117 and payment of the fees as provided by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. It shall be an express condition of each license that the hauler shall comply with all provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1983, § 20.203) 
Sec. 62-89. - Delivery of combustible waste. 
    Commencing on the commercial operation date and at all times thereafter, waste haulers shall (a) deliver to the MBI all combustible waste collected or transported from a site of generation within the city and (b) pay the tipping fee for delivery of such waste at the MBI (unless otherwise provided by contract between the city and the waste hauler). Commencing on the commercial operation date and at all times thereafter, no waste hauler shall deliver combustible waste collected or transported from a site of generation within the city to any disposal site other than the MBI. Waste haulers shall not deliver hazardous waste, or any solid waste other than combustible waste, to the MBI. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, waste haulers shall not be prohibited from transporting combustible waste collected from a site of generation within the city for disposal at any disposal site located outside of the State of Michigan. 
(Code 1983, § 20.204; Ord No. 3-98, § 1, 1-19-98) 
Sec. 62-90. - Compliance with laws, rules and regulations. 
    Waste haulers shall comply with the Act 641 Plan and all applicable federal and state laws, statutes, rules and regulations (including, but not limited to, Act 641 Plan and administrative rules promulgated pursuant to Act 641 Plan) in the collection, transportation, delivery and disposal of combustible waste. Waste haulers shall also comply with all rules and regulations promulgated by the county board of public works for the administration and operation of the MBI and other disposal sites of the county refuse disposal system (see section 62-124). 
(Code 1983, § 20.205) 
Sec. 62-91. - Violations. 
    In addition to any other remedies which the city may have available under this Code or under the laws of the state, a violation of any provision of this article shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the license in accordance with section 14-52. 
(Code 1983, § 20.206) 
Secs. 62-92-62-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GARBAGE AND RUBBISH HAULERS 

Sec. 62-116. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage (rubbish) truck means a self-contained, fully enclosed vehicle used or intended to be used for the pickup transportation for disposal of garbage and/or rubbish. 
(Code 1983, § 20.101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-117. - License-Required; fee. 
    No vehicle shall pick up, haul, transport or be used for the disposal of garbage and/or rubbish in the city without the owner's having obtained for that vehicle a city license and having paid the license fee as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. For the year 1992, the license year for garbage, rubbish and waste haulers shall be March 1 through June 30, 1993. Thereafter, the license year for these haulers shall begin on July 1 and end on June 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1983, § 20.102) 
Sec. 62-118. - Same-Not required. 
    No license shall be required for any person hauling garbage or rubbish on a noncommercial basis either for that person or on a gratuity basis for some other person. 
(Code 1983, § 20.103) 
Sec. 62-119. - Transportation of garbage and rubbish. 
    All garbage and/or rubbish of the city shall be picked up, hauled or transported only in licensed garbage (rubbish) trucks, except as provided in section 62-121. 
(Code 1983, § 20.104) 
Sec. 62-120. - Open vehicles. 
    No person shall transport garbage and/or rubbish in any open vehicle except under the terms and conditions as provided in section 61-121. 
(Code 1983, § 20.105) 
Sec. 62-121. - Open transportation. 
    Transportation of certain items shall be allowed in open vehicles only under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Such items are of such a size or nature that they cannot be transported in a closed vehicle. 
(2)  No loose garbage or rubbish shall be transported in open vehicles. 
(3)  Such items shall be hauled or picked up or transported only in a vehicle licensed by the city. 
(4)  All items transported shall be transported and secured in such a manner as to prevent leakage, blowing or spillage of the items transported or their contents on any public street or private property. 
(5)  Transportation of trash and rubbish containers on trucks designed for such transportation, provided such containers are fully secured and covered so as to prevent all blowing, spillage or leakage. 
(Code 1983, § 20.106) 
Sec. 62-122. - Insurance. 
    All vehicles licensed for trash and/or rubbish hauling shall be insured in an amount of not less than $500,000.00/$1,000,000.00 for injuries to persons and not less than $100,000.00 for injuries to property. All licensees shall file certificates of insurance with the city clerk prior to obtaining a license and shall at all times provide current certificates of insurance for such vehicles during the license period. 
(Code 1983, § 20.107) 
Sec. 62-123. - Inspection. 
    The city shall have the right to inspect all equipment for which a license is required either prior to the issuance of the license or at any time during the period of the license to determine whether the vehicles are or continue to be in compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1983, § 20.108) 
Sec. 62-124. - Compliance with article. 
    All waste haulers shall comply with this article. 
(Code 1983, § 20.109) 
Sec. 62-125. - Refuse collection areas. 
    All garbage, rubbish and other refuse shall be collected only on the days indicated in the areas marked on the map entitled, "Refuse Collection Areas-City of Wyoming, Michigan." 
(Code 1983, § 20.110) 
Sec. 62-126. - Time of collection. 
    No garbage, rubbish or other refuse shall be collected before 6:00 a.m. on any day. 
Chapter 66 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Public improvements by townships, MCL 41.721 et seq., MSA 5.2770(51) et seq.; special assessments notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq. 

Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost means, when referring to the cost of any improvement, the cost of surveys, plans, lands, rights-of-way, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing and construction and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
    Improvement means any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against one or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefitted thereby, in proportion to the benefit to be derived therefrom. 
(Code 1983, § 7.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-2. - City council authority. 
    The city council shall have the power to determine that the whole or any part of the cost of any improvement shall be defrayed by special assessments upon the property especially benefitted, but such determination shall not be made until the preliminary proceedings provided for in section 66-5 shall have been completed. 
(Code 1983, § 7.2) 
Sec. 66-3. - Petition. 
    The city council, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; but, in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Code 1983, § 7.3) 
Sec. 66-4. - Preliminary proceedings. 
    Before determining to make any improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be defrayed by special assessment, the city manager shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, plans and specifications therefor, an estimate of the cost thereof and his recommendations as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which assessments may be paid and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Code 1983, § 7.4) 
Sec. 66-5. - Determination public hearing; notice. 
(a)  A public hearing shall be held before the city council at a time and place to be fixed by it. The city clerk shall cause notice of the time and place of such hearing to be published once in the official newspaper of the city not less than five days prior to the date of such hearing. Such notice shall also state whether the report, plan and estimate is on file with the city manager for public examination. Notice of such hearing shall also be given to each owner of, or party interested in, property to be assessed, whose name appears upon the last local tax assessment records, by mailing such notice by first class mail addressed to such owner or party at the address shown on the tax records at least ten days before the date of such hearing. The last local tax assessment records shall mean the last assessment roll for ad valorem tax purposes which has been reviewed by the local board of review, as supplemented by any subsequent changes in the names or the addresses of such owners or parties listed thereon. Any failure to give notice as required in this chapter shall not invalidate an entire assessment roll but only the assessment on property affected by the lack of notice. In no case shall any special assessment be deemed invalid as to any property if the owner or such party in interest thereof has actually received notice, has waived notice or has paid any part of the assessment. At the time and place specified in such notice for the public hearing, the city council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by order of the city council. 
(b)  The notice shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal, and that an owner or party in interest, or his agent, may appear in person at the hearing to protest the special assessment or may file his appearance or protest by letter and his personal appearance shall not be required. The notice shall further include a statement that the owner or any party having an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment roll if that special assessment was protested at the hearing held for the purpose of confirming the roll. 
(Code 1983, § 7.5) 
Sec. 66-6. - City council determination. 
    After completion of the hearing, the city council may, by resolution, determine to make the improvement and to defray the whole, or any part, of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefitted, in proportion to the benefits thereto. By such resolution the city council shall: 
(1)  Approve the plans and specifications for the improvement and determine the estimated cost thereof; 
(2)  Determine what proportion of the estimate cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefitted and what part, if any, shall be the obligation of the city at large; 
(3)  Determine the number of installments, not to exceed 20 annual installments, in which the special assessment shall be paid and the date of payment for the first installment; 
(4)  Determine the rate of interest to be charged for projects to be paid by installments; in the event any project is financed by borrowing, the interest rate to be charged shall not exceed one percent above the rate for the sale of bonds; and 
(5)  Designate the district or the land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied. By such resolution, the city council may also direct the city manager to obtain firm bids when such work is to be performed under contract. 
(Code 1983, § 7.6) 
Sec. 66-7. - Objection to improvement. 
    No original special assessment roll shall be confirmed except by the affirmative vote of five members of the council if, prior to such confirmation, written objections to the proposed improvement have been filed by owners of property in the district which represents over 50 percent of the assessed value of such district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 7.7) 
Sec. 66-8. - Preparation of the roll. 
    The city manager shall direct the city assessor or his designee to prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the city council, and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large. 
(Code 1983, § 7.8) 
Sec. 66-9. - Filing roll. 
    Upon completion of the special assessment roll, the roll shall be filed with the city clerk for presentation to the city council. 
(Code 1983, § 7.9) 
Sec. 66-10. - Public hearing to review assessment roll; notice. 
    Upon receipt of such special assessment roll, the city council shall order it filed in the office of the city manager for public examination, fix the time and place when it will conduct a public hearing, and review such roll and direct the city clerk to give notice of the hearing. Such notice shall state that the special assessment roll is on file for public inspection with the city manager and that any objections thereto must be filed in writing with the city clerk. It shall further specify the time and place of the hearing to review the roll and shall be published once in the official newspaper of the city not less than five days prior to the date of such hearing. Notice of the hearing shall also be given to each owner of, or party in interest in, property to be assessed, whose name appears upon the last local tax assessment records, by mailing such notice by first class mail addressed to such owner or party at the address shown on the tax records at least ten days before the date of such hearing. The last local tax assessment record shall mean the same as specified in section 66-5. Any failure to give notice as required in this chapter shall not invalidate an entire assessment roll but only the assessment on property affected by the lack of notice. In no case shall any special assessment be deemed invalid as to any property if the owner or the party in interest thereof has actually received notice, has waived notice or has paid any part of the assessment. If any special assessment is declared void by court decree or judgment, then a reassessment against the property may be made. 
(Code 1983, § 7.10) 
Sec. 66-11. - Objections to the roll. 
    Any person deeming himself aggrieved by the special assessment roll may file his objections thereto in writing with the city clerk prior to the close of the review, which written objection shall specify in what respect he deems himself aggrieved. 
(Code 1983, § 7.11) 
Sec. 66-12. - Roll confirmation; installments; determination of interest. 
(a)  The council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land, or any other error appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the council minutes. After such hearing and review, the city council may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. The clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll. Such roll shall, upon confirmation, be final and conclusive. After such hearing the council shall, by resolution, determine the date on which the first installment of the special assessments shall be due, referred to in this chapter as the "installment date," and shall determine the date from which the interest on the unpaid balance of the special assessments shall run, referred to as the "interest date." The treasurer shall issue an initial statement on the first day of the month following the date of the confirmation, such statement to include the total assessment, the installment date, the interest date, and language advising the property owner that he may pay single or multiple installments without being charged interest at any time prior to the interest date. Failure to mail such a statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the property owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(b)  The council may, in the resolution referred to, determine that the entire principal amount of any special assessment imposed for sanitary sewers or water mains against any lot or parcel of land shall be payable at the time that connection is made to the water main or sanitary sewer, as the case may be, and may determine that the special assessment may be paid without interest or with interest not exceeding the maximum rate permitted by law, as the council may determine. 
(Code 1983, § 7.12) 
Sec. 66-13. - Attachment of lien. 
    All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment, shall constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed from the date of confirmation of such roll, and shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land until paid. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created for city taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree, nor shall any act of the city council vacating a special assessment, destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the premises, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. 
(Code 1983, § 7.13) 
Sec. 66-14. - Transmission of assessment roll to city treasurer for collection; certification. 
    The assessment roll shall be transmitted by the city clerk to the city treasurer for collection immediately after confirmation. The city clerk shall attach to such roll a certification, reading substantially as follows: 
I hereby certify that on  (date)  the City Council of the City of Wyoming did confirm the above special assessment roll. 
(Signature) 
Wyoming City Clerk  
Upon receiving the assessment roll from the city clerk, the city treasurer shall determine the total amount of the roll, including the amount which has been assessed to the city at large or to specified funds and the number of installments. 
(Code 1983, § 7.14) 
Sec. 66-15. - Payment plan. 
    The first installment shall be due on the installment date set by the resolution of the city council as provided in section 66-12, together with any interest upon the unpaid balance from and after the interest date to the last day of the month in which the installment date occurs; provided, however, that any fraction of a month shall, for the purposes of computing interest, be considered as a full month. Thereafter, one installment shall be due each year on the anniversary date of the installment date, together with one year's interest on the unpaid balance to the last day of the month in which the anniversary date occurs; provided, however, that when any annual installment shall have been prepaid as is provided in this chapter, then only the interest upon the unpaid balance shall be billed for each year. After each installment has been billed, the installment shall be collected by the city treasurer with the same rights and remedies as provided in the city Charter or state law for the collection of taxes. 
(Code 1983, § 7.15) 
Sec. 66-16. - Collection fee. 
    Each special assessment, or each installment of any assessment when payment is allowed by installment, shall be collected by the city treasurer without a collection fee for a period ending on the last day of the month which the installment date or any anniversary date thereof occurs, and shall include future installments of special assessment rolls confirmed prior to the date of this chapter where the assessment contained no prohibition of a collection fee to be charged on default in payment. If payment is made on or after the first day of the month subsequent to the month on which the installment date or any anniversary date thereof occurs, the city treasurer shall add to such assessment or such installment, together with accrued interest thereon, a collection fee of one-half of one percent of the amount thereof, including accrued interest, and on the first day of each succeeding month he shall add an additional one-half of one percent collection fee until returned to the county on March 1 for collection. 
(Code 1983, § 7.16) 
Sec. 66-17. - Determining actual cost. 
    Upon completion of the improvement and the payment of the cost thereof, the city treasurer shall certify to the city manager the total cost of such improvement. The city manager shall forward this report to the city council, together with the amount of the original roll for such improvement. 
(Code 1983, § 7.17) 
Sec. 66-18. - Deficiency assessments. 
    Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount that may be contributed by the city at large, prove insufficient for any reason to pay the cost of the improvement for which they were made, then the city may make an additional contribution and the city council, to supply the deficiency, may make additional assessments against the several lots and parcels of land, in the same ratio as the original assessments, but the total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement. 
(Code 1983, § 7.18) 
Sec. 66-19. - Special assessment errors. 
    Whenever the city manager shall determine that a special assessment levied upon a single parcel or tract of land is illegal, resulting in no benefit to the owner, was levied in error, or that such assessment violates the policy of the city council not to assess the same property twice for the same type of improvement, then the city manager shall submit a report of the error to the city council for approval, which shall have the power and authority to waive collection of a part or all of such assessment. The city treasurer, upon receiving the report from the city manager of such waiver, shall thereafter make collection on such assessment only in accordance with such report. 
(Code 1983, § 7.19) 
Sec. 66-20. - Court action; delinquent assessments. 
    In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment, together with interest and penalties may be collected by the city by starting court action against the person assessed. If, in any action, it shall appear that by reason of irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city which is a proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Code 1983, § 7.20) 
Sec. 66-21. - Due date or end of month falling on Saturday, Sunday or holiday. 
    Whenever the due date or the end of a month falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday recognized by the United States government, the state or the city, collection of taxes, assessments, fees, interests and penalties, paid to the city, shall be extended to the next working day of the city without any additional fees, penalties or interest being added for that month, if paid on the next working day. Payments received by mail and postmarked on or before the due date, or the extended due date, shall be considered as paid on time, and there shall be no imposition of additional fees, penalties or interest. 
(Code 1983, § 7.21) 
Sec. 66-22. - Standard special assessment rates. 
    Whenever the city council decides to levy special assessments to defray the costs of any improvements, special assessment rates shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5-96, § 1, 3-4-96) 
Chapter 70 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 50; special assessments, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 90. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Permits, fees, and bonds. 
    Where permits are required and authorized in this chapter they shall be obtained upon application to the city engineer upon forms to be furnished by him. Such application shall be accompanied by such fees as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. Any permit issued under this chapter shall be valid only for the period of time stated thereon and may be revoked by the city engineer for failure to comply with this chapter, any rules and regulations adopted pursuant hereto, or any lawful order of the city engineer. Application for a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a covenant by the applicant to complete promptly the work permitted, to observe all pertinent laws and regulations of the city in connection therewith, to repair all damage done to the street surface and installations on, over or within such street, including trees, and to protect and indemnify the city against any claim for damage which may arise or be brought on account of injury to any person or damage to any property resulting from the work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Where liability insurance policies are required to be filed with the application for a permit, they shall be in such amounts as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall, and a copy of such policy or certificate of insurance shall be approved as to form by the city attorney, shall be filed with the city engineer and transmitted by him, together with a copy of the permit, to the city clerk to be retained among the records of the city. Wherever this chapter requires a cash deposit to accompany an application for a permit, such deposit shall be in the amount as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall except as otherwise specified in this chapter. Such deposit shall be held as a reserve to reimburse the city for any expenses which may be incurred by it due to the work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Six months after the completion of the work done under such permit, any unexpended cash deposit shall be refunded to the applicant. In any case where the deposit does not cover all the costs and expenses of the city, the deficit shall be billed to and paid by the applicant. 
(Code 1983, § 50.2) 
Sec. 70-2. - Removal of trees. 
    The city shall have the right to trim or remove any tree on a public right-of-way if in the opinion of the city it is necessary to preserve public safety and/or protect public property. 
Sec. 70-3. - Trees overhanging public property. 
    Should any part of a tree overhang a public right-of-way but the trunk is on private property, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property on which the tree trunk is located to take such corrective action as is provided in section 82-36. 
Sec. 70-4. - Backfilling. 
    All backfilling of excavations shall be in accordance with the city's standard construction specifications. 
Sec. 70-5. - Utility poles. 
    Utility poles shall be placed and located in such streets as approved by the city engineer. 
Sec. 70-6. - Street and sidewalk obstructions. 
(a)  No person shall place any materials or machinery incidental to the construction, demolition or repair of any building in any street without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer, posting a cash deposit and filing an insurance policy or certificate of insurance as required by section 70-1. 
(b)  At least five feet of sidewalk space shall be kept clean and clear for the passage of pedestrians. If construction operations are of such a nature and scope that such passage on the public sidewalk is impracticable, a temporary plank sidewalk with substantial railings or sidewalk shelter shall be installed around such obstruction. 
(c)  If any sign is placed on any public right-of-way including, but not limited to, the parkway, or on any other public property, the city shall have the right to remove the sign immediately. Any sign removed by the city shall be claimed within ten days, otherwise the sign will be destroyed. If the owner or person responsible for the sign wishes it returned, a fee set by resolution of the city council shall be charged for each sign. 
(d)  If any portable basketball hoop is placed on any public right-of-way, except within the end of a local street cul-de-sac, the city shall have the right to remove the portable basketball hoop after providing the owner with ten days written notice. Any portable basketball hoop removed by the city shall be claimed within ten days, otherwise the portable basketball hoop will be disposed of. If the owner or person responsible for the portable basketball hoop wishes it returned, a fee set by resolution of the city council shall be charged for each portable basketball hoop. 
(e)  If a property owner wishes to place a portable basketball hoop within the end of a local street cul-de-sac, the owner shall: 
(1)  Notify all neighbors on the street cul-de-sac. 
(2)  Supervise young children using the portable basketball hoop. 
(3)  Keep the basketball rim behind the back of the curb when not in use. 
(4)  Remove the portable basketball hoop from the public right-of-way if it is determined by the city to interfere with street maintenance or public safety. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § 1, 3-21-94; Ord. No. 4-11, § 1, 5-16-11) 
Sec. 70-7. - Construction procedures; safety standards. 
(a)  All construction procedures shall be in accordance with the city's standard construction specifications, with the exception that tunneling of laterals will be allowed if it is determined that the proper alignment and slope can be maintained on the lateral. 
(b)  All openings, excavations and obstructions shall be constructed and protected in accordance with the city's standard construction specifications, the state occupational safety and health act, and state manual of uniform traffic control devices requirements. 
Sec. 70-8. - Leaves and yard waste in public streets. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Alley means a dedicated public way which affords only secondary means of access to abutting property and is not intended for general traffic circulation, parking, standing or loading. 
(2)  Leaves and yard waste means any grass, leaves, needles, seeds, pods or any other organic material from any deciduous or non-deciduous tree, bush, flower or plant or any branch, twig or other organic material from any tree, bush, flower or plant. 
(3)  Public street means a public dedicated right-of-way which affords traffic circulation and principal means of access to abutting property, including avenue, place, way, drive, boulevard, highway, road, and other thoroughfare, except an alley. 
(4)  Sidewalk means a paved area or designated path provided for use by pedestrian and non-motorized traffic and for purposes of this section will include the area between the sidewalk and the traveled portion of the street. 
(b)  No person shall dump, deposit or in any manner intentionally place any leaves or yard waste in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to leaves or yard waste placed in approved containers, city-approved leaf bags or containers or as allowed during a city-authorized program. 
(d)  Violation of this section shall be a municipal civil infraction as provided in section 1-27 of this Code. For purposes of this section, each day shall be a new violation. 
(e)  Removal. For any property in violation of this section, the city is authorized to notify the owner of such property to remove the leaves or yard waste from the public street. The notice shall be as prescribed in section 1-25 of this Code to the owner as his name appears on the latest assessment roll or the actual occupant, if known. If the owner fails or refuses to comply with the notice, the city may, three business days after the notice, remove the leaves or yard waste from the public street and charge the owner at cost plus 100 percent based upon quarterly hours, a minimum of one hour per lot and may place the charges on the tax roll to be added to the taxes for the property for the next year and/or placing a lien against the subject property. 
    In lieu of the notice required in this section, the city may publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the county when deemed appropriate by the city, that leaves or yard waste not removed by the owner may be removed by the city with the owner charged with the cost under the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2-17, § 1, 5-15-17) 
Secs. 70-9-70-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-36. - Street numbers required on buildings. 
(a)  All primary structures on lots shall clearly display the street numbers of the premises. Such numbers shall be Arabic, with a minimum height of three inches for residential property and six inches for all other types of property. The numbers shall be fastened to and located near the main entrance of the structure, of a color contrasting with its background, and clearly legible from the street. If the structure is a considerable distance from the street or obscured by tree cover, topography, etc., so that the numbers are not clearly visible from the street, the numbers shall be visibly displayed in the location in the front yard. 
(b)  New construction shall comply prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit. 
(Code 1983, § 50.121) 
Sec. 70-37. - Damage and obstruction. 
(a)  No person shall make any excavation in, or cause any damage, to any street within the city except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall park, place or allow any article, thing or obstruction in any street (public right-of-way), except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this article. This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the following: 
(1)  The lawful parking of land motor vehicles (except snowmobiles) within that part of the street which has been reserved for vehicular traffic; 
(2)  The temporary storage of trash and garbage in proper receptacles preparatory for pickup thereof; and 
(3)  The parking, placing or allowing of objects within the street right-of-way in conformance with this chapter. 
The city may remove any object which is parked, placed or allowed in the street right-of-way in violation of this section, and the expense of such removal shall be charged to the person responsible therefor. 
(Code 1983, § 50.1) 
Sec. 70-38. - Street openings, permit required. 
    Any person desiring to make any excavation or opening in or under any street shall first obtain a written permit from the city engineer. No such permit shall be issued until the applicant posts a cash deposit and files a liability insurance policy or certificate of insurance as required by section 70-1. 
(Code 1983, § 50.3) 
Sec. 70-39. - Emergency openings. 
    The city engineer may, if public safety requires immediate action, grant permission to make a necessary street opening in an emergency without issuance of a permit, provided that a permit therefor shall be obtained on the next business day and the provisions of this article shall be met. 
(Code 1983, § 50.4) 
Sec. 70-40. - Construction procedures. 
    All construction procedures shall be in accordance with the city's standard construction specifications. 
(Code 1983, § 40.18) 
Sec. 70-41. - Maintenance of installations in street. 
    Every owner of any sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole or any other excavation, or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon any street which is adjacent to or a part of the property of the owner shall maintain the same and any covers for the same and any gas or electric boxes and tubes thereon in good repair and condition at all times, and shall indemnify and save harmless the city against any claim for damage to property or injury to person which may result therefrom. 
(Code 1983, § 50.8) 
Sec. 70-42. - Removal or relocation of installation in street. 
    The owner of any sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole or any other excavation or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon any street within the city shall remove or relocate such installation as the city engineer may direct. The engineer shall give notice in writing to the owner of such installation directing removal of or relocation of the installation and granting such owner or person a reasonable time, but not less than ten days from the date of such notice, to comply therewith. If the installation has not been removed or relocated within the time specified by such notice, the installation may be removed or relocated by the city, and the cost charged against the owner. 
(Code 1983, § 50.9) 
Sec. 70-43. - Sewer and water connections to be installed prior to paving or resurfacing; cost. 
    Whenever the city council shall determine to pave or resurface any street, all necessary sewer and water connections shall be installed in advance of such paving or resurfacing, and the cost shall be charged against the premises adjacent thereto or to be served thereby. Where such paving or resurfacing is financed, in whole or in part, by special assessment, the cost of such sewer and water connections may be a lien, collected and included as part of the special assessment for the cost of the sewer and water connections so installed. 
(Code 1983, § 50.11) 
Sec. 70-44. - Prohibited openings. 
    No permit to make any opening or excavation in or under a paved street shall be granted to any person within a period of ten years after the completion of any paving or resurfacing thereof; provided, however, that the city engineer may suspend such prohibition where a street opening is required to protect the public health or safety. 
Sec. 70-45. - Removal of encroachment. 
    Whenever there is an encroachment, obstruction or excavation in the street which has not been allowed under the provisions of this article, the same shall be removed forthwith and any excavation refilled. The expense of such removal or refilling shall be charged to the person responsible for such unlawful encroachment, obstruction or excavation. 
(Code 1983, § 50.15) 
Sec. 70-46. - Temporary street closing. 
    The city engineer may temporarily close any street, or portion thereof, which he deems to be unsafe or unsuitable for traffic. He shall cause suitable barriers and signs to be erected on the street, indicating that the street is closed to public travel. When any street, or portion thereof, shall have been closed to public travel, no person shall drive any vehicle on the street except as may be required for any street repair or construction work. No person shall move or interfere with any sign or barrier erected pursuant to this section without authority from the city engineer. 
(Code 1983, § 50.16) 
Sec. 70-47. - Temporary crossing. 
    When directed by the city engineer, temporary crossings shall be provided over open trenches and temporary surfaces shall be placed over backfilled trenches in order to facilitate movement of traffic or to furnish access to abutting property. 
(Code 1983, § 50.17) 
Sec. 70-48. - Moving of oversized and overweight objects. 
(a)  Oversized objects. Objects over ten feet in width or 65 feet in length or 13 feet, five inches in height are oversized. If they are to be moved on city streets, the contractor shall submit an application to the city engineer for approval not less than 24 hours in advance of the move. All moving shall be done on pneumatic-tired trucks, trailers, moving dollies or any combination thereof, and the load shall be distributed so that no axle will carry more than the legal load permitted by state or county regulations, or this Code. Motive power shall be by pneumatic-tired truck or tractor and shall be of sufficient size to handle the load without slipping. Horses or block and tackle for motive power will not be permitted. No moving shall be permitted on Saturdays, Sundays, holidays or the day before a holiday unless authorized by the city. The contractor shall be responsible for furnishing all necessary means of traffic protection before any move is made in the road right-of-way. 
(b)  Overweight objects. Overweight objects may be moved according to the legal limits permitted by the state. The contractor shall submit an application to the city engineer for approval not less than 24 hours in advance of the move. All moving shall be done on pneumatic-tired trucks, trailers, moving dollies or any combination thereof. The regulations of subsection (a) of this section shall also apply. 
(c)  Moving of buildings. If the oversized or overweight object is a building, provisions of section 10-461 et seq. of this Code shall also apply. 
Sec. 70-49. - Notice of commencement of work. 
    Any person performing work under a permit granted pursuant to this chapter, or as approved by the city, shall notify the city engineer at least 24 hours before the work is to be started. No street opening shall be started on Saturdays, Sundays, holidays or the day before a holiday. 
Sec. 70-50. - Restoration of highways. 
    The contractor shall restore the street/right-of-way in accordance with the city's standard construction specifications. Temporary restoration during winter months shall include necessary backfill, surfacing and protection as determined by the city. 
Sec. 70-51. - Display of permit. 
    The foreman in charge of any work being performed under this article shall have in his possession at all times a copy of the permit and of the specifications and conditions under which the work is to be done. 
(Code 1983, § 50.21) 
Sec. 70-52. - Banners. 
    Temporary signs or banners not otherwise permitted under the provisions of this Code may be erected or hung over a public street or alley for a period not to exceed 30 days in accordance with the banner policy adopted by the city council. 
Sec. 70-53. - Street vacation procedures. 
    Any street, highway or alley dedicated to the city for public use may be vacated by the city. The city council shall by resolution set a time for public hearing on the proposed vacation. Notice of the hearing shall be published once in a newspaper published and circulated at least weekly within the city. A copy of such notice shall be sent by the city clerk by certified mail to adjacent property owners and to all public utilities. The hearing shall be scheduled at a regular meeting of the city council but not prior to the expiration of 15 days subsequent to the date of such publication or such mailing. Following the public hearing on the proposed vacation, the city council may by resolution vacate such street, highway or alley and may reserve the right to install and maintain any public utilities. Within 30 days after adoption of the resolution, the clerk shall forward to the state auditor general and to the county register of deeds, certified copies of the resolution. The resolution shall have no force or effect until so recorded. 
(Code 1983, § 50.91) 
Secs. 70-54-70-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING ON STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4-19, adopted Feb. 18, 2019, amended div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 2 pertained to the same subject matter, consisted of §§ 70-76-70-80, and derived from the 1983 Code; Ord. No. 22-94, adopted Nov. 7, 1994; and Ord. No. 6-14, adopted Mar. 3, 2014. 

Sec. 70-76. - Purpose. 
    It is common for weather conditions between December 1 and March 31, and sometimes during other months, to include snowfalls requiring the plowing and removal of snow from city streets. It is also common for weather conditions to change requiring plowing all the way to curbs in order to clear snow cover over catch basins to allow for drainage when the snow and ice melt or rain occurs so as to prevent flooding, refreezing of undrained snowmelt and rain water, and other unsafe conditions. Plowing to the curbs is not possible when cars are parked on the street along the curb. The city recognizes on-street parking is important in some circumstances. In balancing these competing needs, the city is allowing for parking on only one side of the street during overnight hours in the months of December, January, February and March and as such other times as there is a declared snow emergency with the allowed parking alternating on a daily basis to enable snowplowing of both sides of the street. 
(Ord. No. 4-19, § 1, 2-18-19) 
Sec. 70-77. - Odd and even parking for winter and snow emergencies. 
(a)  During the months of December, January, February and March and, at other times during any declared snow emergency: 
(1)  A motor vehicle or a licensed trailer or equipment shall be parked only on that side of the street having even-numbered street addresses on even-numbered calendar days and on that side of the road having odd-numbered street addresses on odd-numbered calendar days between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 p.m. of the same day. 
(2)  On cul-de-sacs on-street parking of a motor vehicle or a licensed trailer or equipment is permitted between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 p.m. of the same day only on even-numbered calendar days. 
(b)  The city manager may declare a snow emergency when the city manager determines that because of current or anticipated winter weather conditions it is prudent to declare such an emergency in order to clear and maintain the streets of the city so as to allow normal and safe vehicular traffic, parking and access, or to open catch basins to improve street drainage. 
(1)  A declared snow emergency shall continue in effect until such time that the city manager declares the emergency to be ended. 
(2)  The city manager shall use reasonable means commensurate with the time and the weather conditions to notify the citizens by website, by publication, by media releases, or by other means a snow emergency declaration. 
(c)  This section shall not allow on-street parking on any street or part of a street on which "no parking" signs are posted on one side of the street. 
(Ord. No. 4-19, § 1, 2-18-19) 
Sec. 70-78. - Violations. 
(a)  A violation of this division is a municipal civil infraction for which a civil fine shall be imposed as provided in section 1-27(e) of this Code. 
(b)  Parking violation notices or municipal civil infraction citations for violations of this division may be issued by any city police officer, police cadet, fire fighter, chief building inspector, building inspector, housing inspector, director of planning/community development/inspections, code enforcement inspector, the city manager, or any other person who the city manager may authorize in writing to issue such parking violation notices or municipal civil infraction citations. 
(1)  A parking violation notice may be placed on or affixed to a vehicle that is parked in violation of this division to notify the owner or driver of the offense. Such notice shall state the date and time of issuance. A notice of violation shall not require payment of any fine or other cost of the violation. 
(2)  A municipal civil infraction citation shall be issued in the same form and manner as for any other parking violation and shall require the same response, appearance, payment of fine and other consequences and actions as any other municipal civil infraction citation. 
(3)  A parking violation notice or municipal civil infraction citation issued pursuant to this subsection shall contain or be accompanied by a statement that failure to move the parked vehicle to comply with the requirements of this division will result in the impoundment of the vehicle as provided in this division. 
(c)  A vehicle parked in violation of this division is a public nuisance per se. 
(d)  If 48 hours has elapsed since a parking violation notice or a municipal civil infraction citation was issued as provided in subsection (b) and the vehicle is still parked or again parked in violation of this division, a city official authorized to issue a parking violation notice or municipal civil infraction citation under subsection (b) may order the impounding of the vehicle so the street can be plowed. 
(e)  Notice of the impounding of the vehicle shall be given in the same manner as for impounding a vehicle under other circumstances in which neither the owner nor operator are present.
