Towing, storage and other fees related to impounding the vehicle shall be due, payable and collectable from the owner of the vehicle and the operator of the vehicle, jointly and severally, in the same manner as for impounding a vehicle under other circumstances. Any vehicle so impounded shall be released from impound in the same manner as for a vehicle impounded under other circumstances in which the owner or operator were not present or as ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(f)  If the city has incurred costs to impound a vehicle as provided in this section, but that vehicle is not so actually removed but is released to the owner or operator prior to such removal, the owner or operator shall pay, in addition to the penalty fixed for such violation, all costs and expenses incurred by the city by reason of the institution of those steps necessary to the removal of that vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4-19, § 1, 2-18-19) 
Sec. 70-79. - Same-Responsibility of owner or operator. 
    In all cases of violation under this division the registered owner and the operator of a vehicle parked in violation of this division are jointly and severally responsible for such violation. The registration of the vehicle shall constitute in prima facie evidence of its ownership. 
(Ord. No. 4-19, § 1, 2-18-19) 
Secs. 70-80-70-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BLOCK PARTIES 

Sec. 70-101. - Permit-Required. 
    Any person desiring to use any public street of the city for any block party or any other social gathering shall first file an application, and thereafter obtain a special highway use permit from the engineering department of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 50.31) 
Sec. 70-102. - Same-Application; contents. 
    Each application shall have attached a petition signed by at least a majority of the owners or tenants of each dwelling unit within the limits of the block party or section of street to be closed. The application shall include the day the party is to be held and the time of such party. Also included shall be a brief description of the type of party, the entertainment, if any, to be provided, and the type of beverages, including alcoholic beverages, to be served at such party. The petition shall include an affidavit signed by the person making the application stating that the required signatures approving the application were obtained. 
(Code 1983, § 50.32) 
Sec. 70-103. - Same-Issuance; validity. 
    Upon review and approval, the traffic engineer shall issue the required permit. The permit shall be valid for the following hours: 
(1)  Weekdays, 5:00 p.m. till dusk; and 
(2)  Saturdays, 12:00 noon till dusk. 
(Code 1983, § 50.33) 
Sec. 70-104. - Streets where allowed. 
    Only local streets with light vehicular traffic are permitted to be used as determined by the traffic engineer. 
(Code 1983, § 50.34) 
Sec. 70-105. - Barricades. 
    Barricades for these streets shall be provided by the city. After approval of the application, barricades will be delivered to the applicant by the city. The applicant will be responsible for the placement prior to and the removal of the barricades after the party. 
(Code 1983, § 50.35) 
Sec. 70-106. - Damage and cleanup. 
    The applicant for the permit shall be responsible for the cost of repairing or replacing any barricade damaged or destroyed. The applicant shall further be responsible for the cleanup of the street and neighboring yards after the party. 
(Code 1983, § 50.36) 
Secs. 70-107-70-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STREET ACCEPTANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-07, adopted Mar. 5, 2007, amended Div. 4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 50.111, 50.112 of the 1983 Code. 

Sec. 70-126. - Preliminary approval; construction of street; fee; final approval. 
    Except as required for plat approval pursuant to the Michigan Subdivision Control Act and the provisions of this Code, the owners or developers of land proposed to be dedicated to the city for public streets, sidewalks, walkways and similar public purposes shall submit a plan to the city showing the proposed improvements. The engineering and planning departments of the city shall review the plans submitted and make recommendations to the city council. The city council shall then review and give preliminary approval or disapproval of the proposed improvements. 
    After preliminary approval, the owners and/or developers shall construct the improvements pursuant to the plan as approved and in accordance with the design standards of the city as provided in section 74-121 of this Code or other applicable design criteria adopted by the city. Prior to review for final approval by the city council, the owners and/or developers shall pay an inspection fee as required by the city's fee schedule. Upon completion of the improvements, the city council shall give final approval to the dedication of the constructed improvements. The decision of the city council shall be based on whether the improvements meet the plans and specifications given preliminary approval and shall be based solely on the criteria and standards adopted by the city and as provided by this division. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 3-5-07) 
Sec. 70-127. - Public and private improvements. 
    The city council will accept dedication of public improvements only when it is necessary to establish public street right-of-way to allow subdivided parcels to have the required public street frontage. In any situation where public street right-of-way is not required, improvements will not be accepted as public improvements. This will not prohibit the city from constructing public improvements within existing or acquired rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 06-07, § 1, 3-5-07) 
Secs. 70-128-70-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SNOW PLOWING 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 70-146. - Special equipment. 
    In addition to all equipment and lighting required by the statutes of the state or by any other section of this Code, any vehicle licensed under this division shall be equipped with a flashing, oscillating or rotating amber light placed in such position as to be visible throughout 360 degrees, which light shall be operated at all times that the vehicle is being used to move, remove or plow snow. 
(Code 1983, § 50.87) 
Sec. 70-147. - Placement of snow. 
    No licensee shall place, deposit, dump or push any snow or ice upon any public right-of-way within the city nor upon any private property without prior consent of the owner. 
(Code 1983, § 50.88) 
Sec. 70-148. - Exemptions. 
    Dump trucks or other vehicles used at the time exclusively for the hauling of snow shall be exempt from the licensing provisions of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 50.89) 
Secs. 70-149-70-170. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License 

Sec. 70-171. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of moving, removing or plowing snow upon public or private property within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1983, § 50.81) 
Sec. 70-172. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to secure a license under this division shall file an application for the license with the city clerk on forms to be provided for by the clerk. The application shall contain the full name of the applicant, his address and telephone number, and the number, make, model, serial number and license plate number of all vehicles which are to be used in the operation of such snow plowing business. 
(Code 1983, § 50.82) 
Sec. 70-173. - Fee. 
    Each application for a license under this division shall be accompanied by a fee for each vehicle covered by the license as established by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 50.83) 
Sec. 70-174. - Term; renewal. 
    Any license granted under this division shall be valid until the following October 1. The license may be renewed for successive terms of one year each upon payment of the annual license fee to the city clerk. The annual license fee shall be in the same amount as the original fee. 
(Code 1983, § 50.84) 
Sec. 70-175. - Insurance. 
    Each licensee shall, before commencing business, furnish to the clerk policies of insurance, evidencing insurance coverage of amounts equal to or greater than those specified by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in the city hall. Such policies shall insure both the city and the licensee and shall provide that such policies may be terminated or canceled only upon the giving of notice of such termination or cancellation to the city not less than ten days prior to the date of termination or cancellation. 
(Code 1983, § 50.85) 
Sec. 70-176. - Decal. 
    For each vehicle for which a license fee has been paid, a license decal shall be issued by the city clerk. Such decal shall contain a registration number which shall correspond to the registration number assigned to the vehicle by the clerk. Such decal shall be affixed in the rear window of the vehicle in such a manner as to be readily seen at all times. 
(Code 1983, § 50.86; Ord. No. 3-99, § 1, 1-4-99) 
Secs. 70-177-70-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS AND DRIVEWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-201. - Permit required for construction, reconstruction or repair; fee. 
    No person, including the owner of the property abutting thereupon, shall construct, reconstruct or repair any public sidewalk, driveway approach, or curb in the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city engineer. The city engineer is hereby authorized to issue such permit upon written application therefor and upon payment of the fee as provided by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. No such permit will be required for sidewalks, driveway approaches or curbs being constructed or repaired under a contract let by the city and performed under the direction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1983, § 50.41) 
Sec. 70-202. - Specifications and setting grade. 
(a)  The city engineer shall forthwith prepare and keep on file standard specifications covering the construction, reconstruction and repair of sidewalks, driveways and curbs. Such specifications and procedures shall be changed and modified as often as may be necessary to ensure that all work is completed in accordance with the most modern and approved methods. 
(b)  Whenever a permit is issued for the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks, driveways or curbs, the city engineer shall as soon thereafter as practicable establish the proper grade therefor and place grade stakes showing the grade, and such sidewalks shall be built according to the grade established by the city engineer. 
(Code 1983, § 50.47) 
Sec. 70-203. - Construction of sidewalks by special assessment. 
    Whenever the city council determines to construct sidewalks within the city and to pay for the sidewalks through the establishment of a special assessment district, the council shall proceed in accordance with the provisions of this article. The provisions of this article shall apply relative to the actual construction of the sidewalks, and such construction shall be under the direction and supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1983, § 50.48) 
Sec. 70-204. - Sidewalk maintenance and repair. 
    No person shall permit any sidewalk adjoining property owned by him to fall into a state of disrepair or to become unsafe. Whenever the city engineer shall determine that a sidewalk is unsafe for use, notice in accordance with the provisions of section 1-25 shall be given to the owner of the lot or premises adjacent to and abutting upon the sidewalk. Such notice shall specify a reasonable time, not less than 15 days within which such repair must be made, and it shall thereafter be the duty of the owner to place the sidewalk in safe condition. If the owner of such lot or premises shall fail or refuse to repair the sidewalk within the time specified, then the city engineer shall have the sidewalk repaired. The cost of such repair shall be charged against the premises which the sidewalk adjoins. If such charges are not paid within 60 days after billing they shall be added to the next tax bill issued by the city and shall thereafter bear the same interest and penalties as the tax bill. 
Sec. 70-205. - Driveway approaches and curb cuts; commercial and residential specifications. 
(a)  Commercial. Commercial driveway approaches and curb cuts shall meet the following specifications: 
(1)  There shall be a distance of not less than 70 feet between an intersecting street right-of-way and the drive opening, measured along the face of the curb. 
(2)  Each driveway opening shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the drive and roadway design criteria, as prepared and kept on file by the director of public works. The design criteria may be changed and modified as often as may be necessary to ensure that work is completed in accordance with the most modern and approved methods. 
(3)  There shall be an island of not less than 30 feet between all drives. 
(b)  Residential. Residential driveway approaches and curb cuts shall meet the following specifications: 
(1)  On corner lots, the distance between a driveway at the property line and the intersecting lot lines at the street intersection shall not be less than the required building setback. 
(2)  Each driveway opening shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the drive and roadway design criteria, as prepared and kept on file by the director of public works. The design criteria may be changed and modified as often as may be necessary to ensure that work is completed in accordance with the most modern and approved methods. 
(Code 1983, § 50.50) 
Sec. 70-206. - Driveways, curbs and gutters; construction; reconstruction and restoration. 
(a)  No driveway approach shall be so constructed that it interferes with municipal or utility facilities such as street lighting poles, utility poles, traffic signal stands, street sign poles, catchbasins, fire hydrants, crosswalks, bus loading zones, underground pipes or ducts, trees or other similar street structures, nor shall any driveway approach be constructed nearer than four feet to any of such street structures. Whenever an owner desires to have a driveway approach located closer than four feet to any street structure, he shall assume all costs necessary to relocate or reconstruct such street structures, as determined necessary by the city engineer. 
(b)  Whenever curbs or curbs and gutters are constructed along a public street, no driveway opening will be provided in the curbs in front of vacant parcels or lots except upon the written request of the property owner. Such written request shall state the purpose or reason for the curb openings and shall be filed with the permit. Whenever an owner desires to abandon, relocate, change, enlarge or decrease a driveway, curb opening or decrease a driveway curb opening or approach which has been properly constructed, he shall apply for approval of such change by the city engineer and shall assume all costs necessary to restore such curb and gutter and the parkway. 
(Code 1983, § 50.51) 
Sec. 70-207. - Removal of snow and other obstructions. 
    The occupant or owner of property abutting upon public sidewalks shall clear and keep such sidewalks clear of snow, ice or obstructions of all kinds within 24 hours of the accumulation or placement of snow, ice or other obstruction. Property owners shall deposit snow from their sidewalk and/or driveway within their own property. If the occupant or owner fails to remove such snow, ice or obstruction from the sidewalk within 48 hours of being notified by the city of such violation, the city may remove or contract for the removal of such ice, snow or obstruction. The cost of removal shall be assessed against the occupant or owner of the property. Notification of violation shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 1-25. 
Sec. 70-208. - Appeals for variances. 
    Any person making an application for a permit to construct, reconstruct or repair sidewalks, curb openings or driveway approaches, who may be denied such permit by the city engineer, may file an appeal in writing to the construction board of appeals, in accordance with the rules established by that board. Upon conducting a hearing, such board may grant a variance from the strict application of the provisions of this article, provided the board shall find that all of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The variance desired arises from a peculiar condition not ordinarily existing and due to the character of the premises or the nature or operation of the business conducted thereon. 
(2)  The variance desired is not against the public interest and is consistent with public safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(3)  The granting of a permit for a variance will not adversely affect the rights of owners of adjacent property. 
(4)  The strict application of the terms of this article will result in imposing an unnecessary hardship upon the owner of the property concerned. 
Secs. 70-209-70-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 70-231. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of constructing, reconstruction or repairing sidewalks, driveway approaches or curbs within the city without having obtained a license therefor from the city clerk. Homeowners repairing or replacing less than 50 square feet of sidewalk shall not be required to obtain a license. 
(Code 1983, § 50.42) 
Sec. 70-232. - Application. 
    Application for a license under this article shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. 
(Code 1983, § 50.43) 
Sec. 70-233. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for licenses issued under this article shall be in such amounts as prescribed by resolution of the city council from time to time and on file in city hall. 
(Code 1983, § 50.44) 
Sec. 70-234. - Bond and insurance. 
    Each licensee shall furnish such bond and be covered by insurance in such amount as is required by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1983, § 50.45) 
Sec. 70-235. - Revocation of license or permit. 
    The city engineer may suspend or revoke any permit, and the city clerk may suspend or revoke any license issued under this article, for incompetency or for failure to comply with the provisions of this article, or for failure or refusal to comply strictly with the rules, regulations, plans or specifications established by the city engineer for the constructions, reconstructions or repair of any item in this article. 
(Code 1983, § 50.46) 
Chapter 74 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 10; floodplain regulations, ch. 38; utilities, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Subdivision Control Act, MCL 560.101 et seq.; minimum standards, MCL 560.259. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Application of chapter; existing lots. 
    This chapter shall not apply to any platted lot recorded prior to June 20, 1978, except for any further dividing. This chapter shall apply to existing outlots. 
(Code 1983, § 70.1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    As-built plans means the revised construction plans in accordance with all approved field changes and measurements. 
    Block means an area of land within a subdivision that is entirely bounded by streets, highways, or ways, except alleys, and the exterior boundary or boundaries of the subdivision. 
    Clear vision zone means as defined in chapter 90. 
    Commercial development means a planned commercial center providing building areas, parking areas, service areas, and areas for turning movement. 
    Essential services means any public or municipal utility or any part or equipment thereof and any public building. A public utility building is included if it is a shelter or building for any part or equipment. 
    Flood fringe district means that portion of the floodplain which carries the shallow, slow moving floodwaters and is the 100-year flood area. 
    Floodway district means that part of the floodplain which carries the deeper, fast moving water and is in the 50-year flood area. 
    Greenbelts or buffer parks means a strip or parcel of land, privately restricted or publicly dedicated as open space. 
    Improvements means any additions to the land. 
    Master development plan or master plan means the master plan for the city, including all studies, maps, charts and policy statements adopted by the planning commission in accordance with Act No. 285 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1931 (MCL 125.31 et seq., MSA 5.2991 et seq.), as amended. 
    Plat means a map, drawing or chart which depicts the plan of the proposed subdivision of land. 
    Public open space means land dedicated or reserved for use by the general public. 
    Public reservation means a portion of a subdivision which is set aside for public use, made available for public use or made available for public acquisition. 
    Public utility means any person or municipality authorized to furnish under regulation transportation, water, gas, electricity, telephone, steam, telegraph, sewage disposal or other utility to the public. 
    Public walkway (pedestrianway) means a public right-of-way dedicated for the purpose of a pedestrian access. 
    Reserve strip means a strip of land in a subdivision which extends across the end of a street proposed to be extended by future platting or a strip which extends along the length of a partial width street proposed by future platting to the minimum permissible width. 
    Right-of-way means land dedicated as a right-of-way. 
    Roadway means that portion of the road right-of-way measured between curb faces and, if there are no curbs, then the finished graded portion if graveled or hard-surfaced area, if they are paved. 
    Subdivision Control Act means the Subdivision Control Act of Michigan, being Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq., MSA 26.430(101) et seq.), as amended. 
(b)  For any other definitions, the definitions of the Subdivision Control Act shall apply and then the definitions of chapter 90 concerning zoning shall apply. 
(Code 1983, § 70.2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 74-3-74-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4-17, adopted July 17, 2017, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II pertained to the same subject manner, consisted of §§ 74-36, 74-37, 74-61-74-65, 74-91-74-94, and derived from the 1983 Code; and Ord. No. 11-04, adopted July 19, 2004. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-36. - Subdivision procedure; preliminary review. 
    Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat, the subdivider may wish to meet informally with the city to investigate the procedures and standards of the city with reference to this chapter and with the provisions of the city land use plan that affects the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. It is the responsibility of the subdivider to: 
(1)  Review the applicable provisions of this Code (the zoning and subdivision chapters), and the standard construction specifications. 
(2)  Review the relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for future widening of thoroughfares. 
(3)  Review the standards for sewage disposal, water supply, erosion control and drainage and flood control of the city and the health standards of the county and the state. 
(4)  Review the Subdivision Control Act (MCL 560.101 et seq.) and the requirements of those state and county agencies which are required by the public act to review and approve the plat. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-37. - Pre-preliminary plat. 
    The property owner may submit a pre-preliminary plat to the city for the proprietor's information and review. The information provided by the owner shall be reviewed by the city planner in accordance with the provisions of section 74-36. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-38. - Pre-preliminary plat-Information required. 
    Should the owner choose to submit a pre-preliminary plat, the following information shall be included in order to properly analyze and advise the property owner at that stage of development: 
(1)  Preliminary lot layout including all lot dimensions. 
(2)  Preliminary street layout including right-of-way dimensions. 
(3)  Preliminary water main and sanitary sewer layout. 
(4)  Preliminary storm sewer layout including outlet locations and detention methods. 
(5)  Preliminary wetland determination. 
(6)  Preliminary estimate of tree stands intended to be retained. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-39. - Procedure. 
    Following review by the city planner and/or any other appropriate city officials, the city planner shall meet with the owner to review the information submitted and the application of city standards and procedures to that information. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Secs. 74-40-74-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT-TENTATIVE APPROVAL 

Sec. 74-51. - Tentative approval-Rights conferred. 
    Tentative approval under this article shall confer upon the proprietor, for a period of one year, approval of lot sizes, lot orientation and street layout. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-52. - Submittal. 
    The proprietor shall file 18 copies of the preliminary plat and other data, as specified in the developers' requirements checklist to the city planner. The preliminary plat must be submitted to the planning department at least 30 days prior to the meeting of the planning commission at which such plan may be considered. One copy shall be in an electronic format acceptable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-53. - Information required. 
    The following information shall be shown on the preliminary plat or submitted with it: 
(1)  Proposed name of subdivision. The name shall not duplicate or closely approximate that of any other subdivision recorded in the county. 
(2)  Legal description of the land to be platted, its area in acres and the name of the city and county. Boundaries of the subdivision shall be drawn in a heavy solid line and described by metes and bounds. 
(3)  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of the proprietor, the planner and designer engineer or surveyor who designed the subdivision layout. 
(4)  The names of abutting subdivisions, layout of streets, indicating street names, right-of-way widths and connections with adjoining platted streets and locations of alleys, easements and public walkways and lot layouts. 
(5)  A location map or vicinity sketch showing the relationship of the proposed plat to the surrounding area. 
(6)  Existing land use and existing zoning of the proposed subdivision and the abutting tracts, including that of any abutting owners. 
(7)  Drawing at scale of 100 feet to one inch or larger. 
(8)  Date, cardinal points and north arrow. 
(9)  A map of the entire area scheduled for development, including future streets if the proposed plat is a portion of a larger holding intended for subsequent development. 
(10)  Six copies of any proposed covenants and deed restrictions, or a statement in writing that none are proposed. Provisions requiring tree planting are encouraged. If common areas are to be reserved for use of the residents of the subdivision, copies of a plan showing how the area will be maintained shall also be submitted. 
(11)  Layout, number and dimension of lots, including front building setback lines. 
(12)  Land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the common use of property owners in the subdivision showing location, width and purpose. 
(13)  The exact location of all floodplain area and regulated wetlands area. 
(14)  Location of any existing and proposed sanitary sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the proposed subdivision, including the location and dimensions of proposed street systems and easements therefor. 
(15)  Contours at two-foot intervals. Topography is to be based on USGS datum. 
(16)  A site report, if the proposed subdivision is not to be served by public water and sewer systems, as described in the rules of the state department of public health. The subdivider shall also furnish three copies of the results of tests of soil percolation certified by a registered professional engineer or registered land surveyor. Such percolation tests to be sufficient in number to be representative of the entire area embraced in the proposed plat, and a minimum of one test per acre. Whenever, by the construction plans for proposed improvements or otherwise, it is indicated that the grade of any lot will be altered in any substantial degree from its grade existent at the time the preliminary plat is submitted, such percolation tests shall be made at the grade contemplated upon completion of such improvements or filling or excavation operations; provided, however, that if a lot is to be filled, percolation tests shall be submitted at the original and final grade. At the option of the subdivider, if provided in writing, the submission of percolation tests, as to the lots so affected, may be deferred to a date later than submission of the preliminary plat but no later than submission of the final plat. 
(17)  A statement indicating the proposed use to which the subdivision will be put, along with a description of any type of residential buildings and number of dwelling units contemplated or the type of business or industry so as to reveal the effect of development on traffic, fire hazards or population density. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-54. - Review procedure. 
    The following review procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  The city shall place the preliminary plat on the agenda of the planning commission as soon as reasonably possible, at which time the city shall schedule a public hearing on the proposed subdivision, provided all the conditions are met. No plat shall be acted on by the commission without affording a hearing thereon. Notice shall be sent to the person by regular mail of the time and place of such hearing not less than five days before the date fixed. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the platted land and within 600 feet according to the names which appear in the assessor's office. 
(2)  The planning commission shall review the preliminary plat and any comments from the city and from the public hearing. If all conditions have been satisfactorily met, it shall recommend to city council tentative approval of the preliminary plat. 
(3)  If the preliminary plat does not meet all requirements, the planning commission shall notify the proprietor of this fact by letter, giving its reasons for disapproval, the earliest date for resubmission of the plat and any additional information required. The city council shall receive a report of the findings by the planning commission and its recommendation for disapproval. 
(4)  The planning commission shall give its report to the city council as soon as reasonably possible after the public hearing. 
(5)  The city council shall review the preliminary plat and shall approve or disapprove such plat. The city council shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor or set forth in writing its reasons for rejection and requirements for tentative approval. If the requirements and conditions of this code have been met, the city council shall grant tentative approval to the preliminary plat. 
(6)  The preliminary plat shall be approved or returned to the proprietor with reasons for disapproval as follows: 
a.  Within 60 days after submission if a pre-preliminary plat was submitted and reviewed. 
b.  Within 90 days after submission if no pre-preliminary plat was submitted and reviewed. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Secs. 74-55-74-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PRELIMINARY PLAT-FINAL APPROVAL 

Sec. 74-61. - Final approval-Rights conferred. 
    Final approval of the preliminary plat under this article shall confer upon the proprietor for a period of two years from date of approval, the rights granted under the Subdivision Control Act. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the city council. Written notice of the extension shall be sent by the city council to the other approving authorities. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-62. - Submittal. 
    Submittal of the preliminary plat for final approval shall be according to the following procedure: 
(1)  The proprietor, upon receiving tentative approval from the city council, shall submit the preliminary plat to all authorities as required by the Subdivision Control Act, including, as appropriate, for approval or rejection: 
a.  County drain commission; 
b.  State department of transportation; 
c.  State department of natural resources; 
d.  State department of environmental quality; and 
e.  State health department. 
(2)  For informational purposes the proprietor shall notify: 
a.  County plat board; 
b.  All public utilities serving the area; and 
c.  The superintendent of the school district serving the area. 
(3)  Eighteen copies of the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the city for final approval by the planning commission and city council prior to the expiration of the tentative approval. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-63. - Information required. 
    Information required . The following information shall be shown on the preliminary plat or submitted to the city planner with it: 
(1)  A list of all such authorities as required by the Subdivision Control Act to the city planner, certifying that the list shows all authorities as required. The proprietor shall also provide approved copies of the plat from each of the required authorities. 
(2)  Complete metes and bounds descriptions of the subdivision boundary. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-64. - Procedure. 
    Procedures . The following procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  The city shall place the preliminary plat on the agenda of the planning commission as soon as reasonably possible after the filing date. At the meeting, the planning commission shall review the preliminary plat and the comments of the appropriate county and state officials indicated in subsection 74-62(1) of this division and shall make recommendations to the city council as to final approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat, including any reasons for a recommendation of disapproval. 
(2)  After final recommendation on the preliminary plat by the planning commission, the city planner shall place the preliminary plat on the agenda of the next regular city council meeting. At that meeting, or within a period of 20 days from receiving the recommendation of the planning commission, the city council shall consider the review and recommendations of the planning commission, city staff for compliance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat standards. 
(3)  If the preliminary plat conforms substantially to the plat approved tentatively by the city council and has met all conditions specified for tentative approval, the city council shall give final approval to the preliminary plat. 
(4)  The city clerk shall promptly record on the copy of the preliminary plat to be returned to the proprietor the approval or attach the rejection with reasons for such rejection. 
(5)  No construction of improvements shall be commenced until the subdivider has: 
a.  Received approval of the preliminary plat by the city council; and 
b.  Entered into an agreement with the city for construction of all required improvements and submitted a performance bond to ensure the specified improvements be completed in accordance with the approved plan. 
(6)  A grading plan shall be required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Secs. 74-65-74-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 74-71. - Survey and true plats to be made and submitted. 
    Following final approval of the preliminary plat by the city council, the proprietor shall obtain a survey with five true plats thereof to be made by a licensed surveyor for distribution to the appropriate municipal, county and state agencies. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-72. - Submittal. 
    Final plats in six paper prints of the final plat, along with the application, shall be submitted to the city planner subject to the following: 
(1)  A final plat shall not be accepted after the date of expiration of the preliminary plat approval. 
(2)  The city planner shall place the final plat on the agenda of the planning commission for the next regularly scheduled meeting at least 30 days after the filing date. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-73. - Information required. 
(a)  All final plats of subdivided land shall comply with the provisions of survey, mapping and certification requirements in the Subdivision Control Act. 
(b)  An abstract of title shall be submitted certified to the date of the proprietor's certificate to establish recordable ownership interest and any other information deemed necessary for the purpose of ascertaining whether the proper parties have signed the plat, or a policy of title insurance currently in force, covering all of the land included within the boundaries of the proposed subdivision. 
(c)  A copy of the receipt from the city treasurer that all engineering inspection fees and other charges and deposits, as provided in this chapter, have been paid shall be submitted. 
(d)  Final engineering construction plans for all improvements to be constructed in connection with the proposed plat in accordance with standards and specifications of the city engineer and this Code. If the subdivider cannot complete such work within the period of time as required by the conditions of city approval for all public improvements, it shall be the subdivider's responsibility to provide a performance bond or to take such steps as may be necessary to ensure performance, which may be in the form of a written agreement between the city council and the developer. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Sec. 74-74. - Procedure. 
(a)  Review; approval by planning commission. The final plat shall be reviewed by the city planner, city engineer and planning commission as to compliance with the approved preliminary plat and plans for utilities and other improvements. Upon determination that the final plat satisfies all city and state requirements, the planning commission shall approve the final plat, and such approval shall be entered in writing on the plat by the chairman or secretary of the planning commission. 
(b)  Action by city council. After approval of the final plat by the planning commission, the city council shall review and take action on the final plat at the next regular meeting after the date of submission. The city council shall give reasons for any disapproval and return the plat and the reasons to the proprietor. If the requirements and conditions of this Code have been met, the city council shall grant final approval to the plat. 
(c)  Performance guarantee. The city shall require all improvements and facilities to be constructed or, in lieu thereof, a performance guarantee shall be provided to the city before final plat approval. The performance guarantee may be in the form of a cash deposit, irrevocable letter of credit or performance bond, in an amount sufficient to ensure the construction of unfinished improvements and facilities. No reductions in the performance guarantee related to partial completion of improvements or of facilities shall be allowed, unless it is a cash deposit. If any of such improvements are not completed by the completion date specified in an agreement between the city and the developer, the city shall have the right to complete the work, either by city employees or by outside contractors, and draw upon the performance guarantee for payment. No building or occupancy permits shall be issued by the city until all work is completed and approved by the city, except that up to three building permits may be issued for model homes, as per section 74-176. 
(d)  Subsequent approvals; disapproval. Upon the approval of the final plat by the city council, the subsequent approvals shall follow the procedure set forth in the Subdivision Control Act. 
(e)  Certificate of approval; filing and recording fees. The clerk shall transcribe a certificate of approval of the city council on the final plat and deliver all copies to the clerk of the county plat board, together with the filing and recording fee required by the Subdivision Control Act. 
(f)  Return to county treasurer; issuance of new certificate. A final plat received by the state treasurer more than one year following the date of approval of the county treasurer shall be returned to the county treasurer who shall make a new certificate, currently dated, relative to paid or unpaid taxes, special assessments and tax liens or titles. 
(g)  Transmission of copies of final plat. The city clerk shall transmit one paper print copy to the planning commission, one paper print to the city planner, one paper print to the city engineer and retain one paper print copy temporarily in the files of the city council. 
(h)  Filing. After all the approvals mentioned in subsection (d) of this section have been obtained, and the state treasurer receives notification of the recording of such plat, he shall return one completely transcribed copy to the city clerk for filing as a matter of permanent record. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Secs. 74-75-74-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DIVISION OF PLATTED LOTS 

Sec. 74-80. - Division of platted lots. 
    The partitioning or dividing of lots, outlots or other parcels of land in a recorded plat within the city is permitted in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(1)  Before division of a platted lot or parcel is made, written application therefor shall be made to the city assessor as follows: 
a.  The application shall be signed by all parties in interest and include the legal description of the parcels for the requested real estate division. 
b.  Two plot plans shall be submitted showing dimensions of the parcels resulting from the proposed division. The city assessor shall have the authority to require that the plot plan is prepared by a registered land surveyor when in the judgment of the city assessor the proposed courses and measurements may be difficult to verify and ascertain. 
c.  The application shall be accompanied by a certificate from the city treasurer showing that the appropriate fee has been paid for all of the parcels resulting from the division and certifying the tax status of the property proposed to be divided. 
(2)  No division of a platted lot or parcel shall be permitted in violation of the Subdivision Control Act or when such division results in more than four resultant parcels. 
(3)  No division of a platted lot or parcel shall be permitted while there remain unpaid real estate taxes on the lot or parcel. 
(4)  Upon submission of proper application, the city assessor may, in accordance with the provisions of this article, permit division of a platted lot or parcel into two, three or four parts when the resulting parcels each satisfy the minimum lot size requirements of the zoning provisions. 
(5)  No division of a platted lot or parcel shall be made which creates a parcel of land not having reasonable access to a public street or dedicated right-of-way. 
(6)  Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship, the board of zoning appeals, may approve division of a platted lot or parcel when resulting parcels are less than the minimum requirements of the zoning code when it is determined that the proposed division would allow the development of the land in such manner as to be compatible with the spirit and purpose of the zoning code or where the property is presently developed and the proposed division creates parcels conforming to existing development and use. 
(7)  When division of a platted lot or parcel has been approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, such approval shall be noted upon the application which shall be filed with the city assessor. 
(Ord. No. 4-17, § 1, 7-17-17) 
Secs. 74-81-74-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENGINEERING DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 74-121. - Construction in accordance with design standards. 
    All streets, alleys and roadways, pedestrian or nonmotorized ways and sidewalks, utilities and other required improvements in any subdivision shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the current design standards of the city, as published by the city and as may be periodically amended. 
Secs. 74-122-74-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLANNING STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES FOR LOTS 

Sec. 74-176. - Lot requirements. 
(a)  General description. The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision as well as for the type of development and use contemplated. Residential lots shall be of such size as to permit a variety of house types which shall be in general conformance with contiguous development, to provide side yards for desirable access, light, air, privacy and safety from fire hazards, and to provide for setbacks from the street line and allow sufficient space for household purposes. 
(1)  Access. All lots shall abut by their full frontage on a properly dedicated street. Lots, other than corner lots, shall not be permitted to front onto two streets. Backup lots to major thoroughfares are permitted with approval of the planning commission. 
(2)  Width. The minimum width of any residential lot shall be governed by the existing zoning requirements for that district. 
(3)  Depth. No lot shall be less than 120 feet in depth and the depth of a lot shall not exceed a depth to width ratio of two to 21/2 to one except where the planning commission shall deem that there are topographic, boundary or other circumstances unique to the property or lands surrounding it. 
(4)  Area. The width and depth of the lot shall be such that minimum lot areas will be in accordance with the zoning provisions. 
(5)  Corner lots. Corner lots shall be provided an extra 20 feet of width sufficient to permit the maintenance of building setback lines on both the front and side street lines in order to protect similar setbacks on both the front and side street which exist or are planned. 
(6)  Backup lots. Lots which back into such features as freeways, arterial streets, shopping centers, or industrial properties, except where there is a marginal access street, unless a secondary access is provided, shall incorporate in the lot depth for buffering purposes an additional 20 feet. 
(7)  Industrial or commercial lots. No lot or parcel zoned as commercial shall be platted that is less than 65 feet in width, and no lot or parcel zoned as industrial shall be platted that is less than 100 feet in width. The minimum depth for commercial lots shall be 150 feet and 200 feet for industrial lots. The area of such lot or parcel shall be sufficient in size as to provide sufficient area for off-street parking and loading in accordance with the requirements of the zoning provisions. 
(8)  Lot division or split. The division of a lot in a recorded plat, shall be in accordance with the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. Any person desiring a lot split shall deposit the necessary fees as provided in section 74-175. Once the city has granted a preliminary plat (tentative approval) to a plat, no lot splits are allowed within the proposed plat until the plat has received final plat approval and has been recorded. 
(9)  Building and setback lines. Building and setback lines shall conform to the requirements of the city zoning provisions. 
(10)  Side lot lines. Side lot lines shall be arranged in relation to each other so that the building width of the lot will not be reduced to unusable proportions at either the front or rear setback lines. Lot boundaries along sides and rear of lots shall be made up of straight lines. 
(11)  Developer model homes. Once the city has granted preliminary plat final approval to a plat, building permits may be obtained by the developer for up to three model homes, provided that the nearest points of the lot lines of those lots intended for model homes are located within 300 feet of the existing improved public street for access to model home lots, as measured along proposed subdivision streets to model home lots. 
(b)  Uninhabitable areas. Lands deemed by the planning commission to be uninhabitable shall not be platted for residential purposes, or for uses that may in the judgment of the planning commission increase the danger to health, life or property, or increase the flood hazard. Such lands within a proposed subdivision shall be set aside for other uses, such as parks or other open space. 
(c)  Future arrangements. Where parcels of land are subdivided into unusually large lots (such as when large lots are required for septic tank operations) the parcels shall be arranged, where feasible, so as to allow for resubdividing into smaller parcels in a logical fashion. 
(d)  Division of platted lots. The partitioning or dividing of lots, outlots or other parcels of land in a recorded plat within the city is permitted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Before division of a platted lot or parcel is made, written application therefor shall be made to the city assessor as follows: 
a.  The application shall be signed by all parties in interest showing the legal description of the parcels from the requested real estate division. 
b.  Two plot plans shall be submitted showing dimensions of the parcels resulting from the proposed division. The city assessor shall have authority to require that the plot plan be prepared by a registered land surveyor when in the judgment of the city assessor the proposed courses and measurements may be difficult to verify and ascertain. 
c.  The application shall be accompanied by a certificate from the city treasurer showing that the appropriate fee has been paid for each of the parcels resulting from the division and certifying the tax status of the property proposed to be divided. 
d.  An opinion of title signed by an attorney at law or a policy of title insurance of current date evidencing that the persons signing the application for division represent all parties interested in the real estate proposed to be divided shall be furnished. 
(2)  No division of a platted lot or parcel shall be permitted in violation of the Subdivision Control Act or when such division results in more than four resultant parcels. 
(3)  No division of a platted lot or parcel shall be permitted while there remain due and unpaid real estate taxes with respect thereto. 
(4)  Upon submission of proper application, the city assessor may in accordance with the provisions of this chapter permit division of a platted lot or parcel into two, three or four parts when the resulting parcels each satisfy the minimum lot size requirements of the zoning provisions. 
(5)  No division of platted lot or parcel shall be made which creates a parcel of land not having reasonable access to a public street or dedicated right-of-way. 
(6)  Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardship, the board of zoning appeals, after report and recommendation from the city planning commission, may approve division of a platted lot or parcel when resulting parcels are less than the minimum requirements of the zoning provisions when it is determined that the proposed division would allow the development of the land in such manner as to be compatible with the spirit and purpose of the zoning provisions or where the property is presently developed and the proposed division creates parcels conforming to existing development and use. 
(7)  When division of platted lot or parcel has been approved in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, such approval shall be noted upon the application which shall be filed with the city assessor. 
(Code 1983, §§ 70.17, 70.23) 
Sec. 74-177. - Block requirements. 
    The size and shape of blocks shall be appropriate for the type of lots and land used proposed. Blocks shall be designed so as to permit good lot orientation, topography, safe street design and economical use of the land, and may be bounded by streets, railroad right-of-way, waterway or other definite barrier. 
(1)  Length. Length of blocks between intersecting streets shall be no less than 500 feet nor more than 1,250 feet unless greater or smaller dimensions are required or accepted by the planning commission during preliminary plat review. 
(2)  Width. A block shall be so designed as to provide two tiers of lots and shall not be less than 240 feet in width, except where lots back into a major thoroughfare, natural feature or subdivision boundary. 
(3)  Nonresidential blocks. Blocks intended for purposes other than residential shall be especially designed for such purposes and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking and loading in accordance with the requirements of the zoning provisions. 
(4)  Block frontage. A block frontage shall mean property abutting on one side of a street and lying between the two nearest intersecting or intercepting streets, or between the nearest intersecting or intercepting street and railroad right-of-way, waterway or other natural topographic boundary. 
(Code 1983, § 70.18) 
Sec. 74-178. - Other planning requirements. 
(a)  Modification of intended use. Wherever property is proposed for subdividing with the intention that it shall have a use different than as zoned, such use shall be stated in an application for an amendment to the zoning or in a separate statement filed with the planning commission. Conformance with the objectives of the land use plan shall be required so as to ensure general uniformity of land uses within blocks and neighborhoods. 
(b)  Use conformance. Property use and area restrictions shall be in accordance with the zoning provisions and the floodplain provisions. 
(c)  Business or commercial lots. Business or commercial lots shall bear a reasonable relation in number to the probable number of families constituting the purchasing power of surrounding tributary area. The planning commission shall recommend the location of business and commercial lots in accordance with the land use plan and zoning provisions. 
(d)  Commercial or industrial modification. Modifications of this chapter must be sought prior to initiation of the platting process and in accordance with section 74-211 and shall be specifically for commercial or industrial developments, including shopping districts, wholesaling areas and planned industrial districts. However, adequate provisions shall be made for off-street parking, buffering, loading areas and traffic circulation. 
(e)  Areas subject to flooding. Any areas which are subject to flooding, inundation by stormwater or within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or have inadequate drainage, shall not be platted for any use so as to increase danger to life, health or property. If the planning commission determines that a flood problem does exist, it shall reject all or part of the proposed plat lying within the floodplain or area subject to flooding. Areas of land lying within a floodplain shall require compliance with the Subdivision Control Act and review by the state department of natural resources. The proprietor may show by engineering site plans that a change in the topography will eliminate flooding and shall demonstrate that any planned topographical change will not aggravate the flood hazard beyond the limits of the plat. 
(f)  Public sites and open spaces. Where a site for a park, playground, playfield, school, library, fire station or other public use is deemed necessary by the planning commission to fulfill the objectives of the land use plan, the commission may recommend the reservation of such areas within the development. Reservation of other public open spaces may be required where deemed necessary by the planning commission for preservation of historic sites and scenic areas or for a particular type of development proposed in the subdivision but not anticipated in the land use plan. Dedication of planting strips of buffer parks may be required by the planning commission in areas where they deem it desirable to separate and protect residential subdivisions from adjacent commercial developments, highways, streets and railroads or any obnoxious use. Such strips shall be a minimum of 20 feet wide and shall not be a part of the normal roadway right-of-way or utility easement. 
(g)  Public reserve strips. A one-foot reserve may be required to be placed at the end of dead-end streets which terminate at subdivision boundaries and between half-streets. These reserves shall be deeded in fee simple to the city for future street purposes. 
(h)  Protection of natural features. Due regard shall be shown for all natural features, such as large trees, exceptionally fine groves of trees, watercourses, scenic points, historic spots and similar community assets which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the subdivision. Earth moving and the removal of trees prior to plat review by the city is strongly discouraged. Provisions shall be made to retain trees within the plat wherever practical. 
(Code 1983, § 70.19; Ord. No. 11-04, § 2, 7-19-04) 
Secs. 74-179-74-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VARIANCES 

Sec. 74-211. - Recommendation by planning commission; findings of fact. 
    The city planning commission may recommend to the city council a variance from the provisions of this chapter on a finding that undue hardship may result from strict compliance with specific provisions or requirements of the chapter or that application of such provision or requirement is impracticable. The planning commission shall only recommend variances that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required in this section, the planning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variances shall be recommended unless the planning commission makes the following finding of facts: 
(1)  There are such special circumstances or conditions affecting the property that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would clearly be impractical or unreasonable. In such cases, the subdivider shall first state his reasons in writing as to the specific provision or requirements involved and submit them to the planning commission. 
(2)  The granting of the specified variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the area in which the property is situated. 
(3)  Such variance will not violate the provisions of the Subdivision Control Act. 
(4)  The planning commission shall include its findings and the specific reasons therefor in its report of recommendations to the city council and shall also record its reasons and actions in its minutes. 
(5)  Such variance will not have the effect of nullifying the purpose of this chapter and the land use of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 70.20) 
Sec. 74-212. - Topographical; physical limitation. 
    In the case of a proposed subdivision when it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of this chapter would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography, other physical conditions or other conditions which are not self-inflicted, or that these conditions would result in inhibiting the achievement of the objectives of this chapter, the planning commission may recommend to the board of appeals that variance modification or a waiver of these requirements is granted. 
(Code 1983, § 70.21) 
Sec. 74-213. - Planned residential development and cluster subdivision. 
(a)  The developer may request a variance from specified portions of this chapter in the case of a planned residential development or cluster subdivision. If in the judgment of the planning commission such a plan provides adequate public spaces and includes provisions for efficient circulation, light, air and other needs, it shall make findings as required in this section. The planning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivisions and the probably effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. The planning commission shall report to the city council whether: 
(1)  The proposed project will constitute a desirable and stable community development; and 
(2)  The proposed project will be in harmony with adjacent areas. 
(b)  Application for the development under this section shall be made in writing and shall be supplemented with maps, plans or other additional data which may aid the planning commission and city council in the analysis of the proposed plat. 
(Code 1983, § 70.22)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 77-1-77-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS APPLICABLE AFTER OCTOBER 31, 2002 

Sec. 77-26 - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002) ("Act") and other applicable law, and to ensure that the city qualifies for distributions under the Act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-27. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-28. - Terms defined. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Act means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002), as amended from time to time. 
    City means the City of Wyoming. 
    City council means the city council of the City of Wyoming or its designee. This section does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the city council. 
    City manager means the city manager or his or her designee. 
    Permit means a non-exclusive permit issued pursuant to the Act and this article to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities. 
    All other terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the Act, including without limitation the following: 
    Authority means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Authority created pursuant to section 3 of the Act. 
    MPSC means the Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "commission" in the Act. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
    Public right-of-way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunication facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of Title III of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications provider, provider and telecommunications services mean those terms as defined in section 102 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2102. Telecommunication provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this article only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(1)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(3)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-29. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in the Act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with section 6(1) of the Act. A telecommunications provider shall file one copy of the application with the city clerk, one copy with the city manager, and one copy with the city attorney. Upon receipt, the city clerk shall make two copies of the application and distribute one copy to the city's director of public works and one copy to the city engineer. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the Act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with section 6(5) of the Act. 
(c)  Confidential information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, pursuant to section 6(5) of the Act, the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application fee. Except as otherwise provided by the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time non-refundable application fee in the amount of $500.00. 
(e)  Additional information. The city manager may request an applicant to submit such additional information which the city manager deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the city manager. If the city and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the city, the city or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in section 6(2) of the Act. 
(f)  Previously issued permits. Pursuant to section 5(1) of the Act, authorizations or permits previously issued by the city under section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251 and authorizations or permits issued by the city to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(g)  Existing providers. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act, within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the city as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251, shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the Act, a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the $500.00 application fee required under subsection (d) above. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional 180 days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in section 5(4) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-30. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Approval or denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the city manager. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the Act, the city manager shall approve or deny an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under section 77-29(b) of this article for access to a public right-of-way within the city. Pursuant to section 6(6) of the Act, the city manager shall notify the MPSC when the city manager has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The city manager shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of permit. If an application for permit is approved, the city manager shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the Act. 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to section 15(4) of the Act, the city manager may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond requirement. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the Act, and without limitation on subsection (c) above, the city manager may require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. If a bond is required, it shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-31. - Construction/engineering permit. 
    A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across, or under the public rights-of-way in the city without first obtaining a street permit as required under section 70-38 of this Code, as amended, for excavations or openings in or under the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such permit. To the extent the fee requirements of any city ordinance or resolution are in conflict with this section 77-31, those fee requirements are repealed. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-32. - Conduit or utility poles. 
    Pursuant to section 4(3) of the Act, obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this article does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-33. - Route maps. 
    Pursuant to section 6(7) of the Act, a telecommunications provider shall, within 90 days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the city, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the city. The route maps should be in electronic format unless and until the MPSC determines otherwise, in accordance with section 6(8) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-34. - Repair of damage. 
    Pursuant to section 15(5) of the Act, a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the city, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-35. - Establishment and payment of maintenance fee. 
    In addition to the non-refundable application fee paid to the city set forth in section 77-29(d) above, a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the city's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to section 8 of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-36. - Modification of existing fees. 
    In compliance with the requirements of section 13(1) of the Act, the city hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of section 13(4) of the Act, the city also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the city's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under section 8 of the Act. The city shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this article, in compliance with the requirement of section 13(4) of the Act. To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the city's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the city, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-37. - Savings clause. 
    Pursuant to section 13(5) of the Act, if section 8 of the Act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under section 77-36 above shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-38. - Use of funds. 
    Pursuant to section 10(4) of the Act, all amounts received by the city from the authority shall be used by the city solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the city from the authority shall be deposited into the Major Street Fund and/or the Local Street Fund maintained by the city under Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of 1951. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-39. - Annual report. 
    Pursuant to section 10(5) of the Act, the city manager shall file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-40. - Cable television operators. 
    Pursuant to section 13(6) of the Act, the city shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-41. - Existing rights. 
    Pursuant to section 4(2) of the Act, except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the city may have under a permit issued by the city or under a contract between the city and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 22-02, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Sec. 77-42. - Compliance. 
    The city hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this ordinance is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The city shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Exempting certain route maps from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, as provided in section 77-29(c) of this article, to the extent permitted by law; 
(2)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with section 77-29(f) of this article; 
(3)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the $500.00 application fee, in accordance with section 77-29(g) of this article; 
(4)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the city, in accordance with section 77-34(a) of this article; 
(5)  Notifying the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with section 77-34(a) of this article; 
(6)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with section 77-34(a) of this article; 
(7)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in section 77-34(b) of this article; 
(8)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with section 77-34(c) of this article; 
(9)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with section 77-34(d) of this article; 
(10)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with section 77-35 of this article; 
(11)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the city's right-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with section 77-36 of this article; 
(12)  Submitting an annual report to the authority, in accordance with section 77-39 of this article; and
